main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros:
Good up-to-front, 1st year salary.

Many good, experienced/senior engineers are available - great for learning through Q&A.

Most of the time, IPT's are very experienced and quick to realize what is going on in the program.

Lots of opportunities and resources to learn new skills and methods.

Many programs available for you to get in.



Once each program/contract ends, your manager usually helps you get into another program (depends on manager and/or your sector though).

Good benefits - 
>>medical (value is declining over time, but still quite okay), 
>>DENTAL (especially great), 
>>vision, 
>>pension (have to stay in the company for 3 years, though), 
>>quite flexible and abundant PTO hours (3 weeks including 1 week off at the end of the year, and increases quite proportionally with length of stay at this company, but NO PAID SICK DAY),
>>education support (have to stay in the company for 2 years since the date company pays for the class(es) in exchange)
>>depending on your sector and your program, you might be granted a company laptop for you to work at home.
cons:
1.  Lots of bureaucracy and mismanagement that often leads to program failure : 

>>Program management scared of reporting "bad news" to upper management and hide it until the program  runs out of money - especially if they're the ones who caused trouble.

>>Lack of diversity in program management section: management experienced in one or two discipline(s) only (the one(s) they've been working for their whole life...), thus they really lack full understanding of how the WHOLE SYSTEM works   (sorry to say, but even interns and junior engineers can see it...).

>>For fast-paced programs, too many unnecessary meetings and documentation requirement exist. 

>>For fast-paced programs, company is NOT willing to pay as much as they need and usually start TOO late. 
>>>Upper management has very unrealistic expectation - thinks engineering problems are very easy to solve (as if it can be done with a click of a button when there were not enough software for the engineers to use!! They also were not willing to pay for development of such software...).



2.  LOTS of unethical behaviors not caught and not punished, because it was done one-on-one/privately and not left on paper.

> These are real-time examples:
>>Example 1, lots of managers look behind your back secretly when they pass by your desk/cubicle. For some of these managers, even less than a minute-long talk is not allowed. When they catch their employees talking for few seconds, they use that as an excuse to give you more work and less staff support for your team. This is especially apparent for tight-budget programs.

>>Example 2, some managers make junior engineers to do certain thing in certain method with very short period of time and they announce it to whole program members (without the junior engineer's consent). If it turns out that the methodology is wrong, they blame on the junior engineer for doing it wrong AND out of time. The manager then lies to his functional manager (who is also the junior engineer's functional manager) when he talks with the functional manager in his room. The junior engineer could not blame him, because the manager only directed him/her verbally, not through email (usually takes too long to explain through email anyway). 

>>Example 3, a fellow junior engineer stole another junior, but more senior engineer's effort/work (to make himself look better to the manager) and always criticize more senior engineer in front of his/her manager (again, to make himself look better compared to more senior engineer).

>>Example 4, a manager tells junior engineer during one-on-one end-of-year performance review that he/she has to work more "green time" in order to get highest score on performance review. The junior engineer is already overwhelmed (physically and mentally) with working overtime for his/her HIGHLY under-staffed section of program. Also, this is supposed to be illegal and the whole program contract is supposed to be terminated by the government if the government finds out about this. 
>>>FYI: The highest score yields only 3.0% to 3.5% increase in salary, which barely meets inflation. The score is only given to very few people among 100's of employees.



3. VERY HARD to get one level promoted - your level of expertise, your contribution, and length of stay does not matter. 
>>Company always find a reason to NOT increase junior engineer's salary, making the junior engineers to leave. 
>>Average salary increase rate is 2% - 2.5% per year for engineers - they can get at least 10% increase when they move to another company!!!!!
>>>Even after hearing about these, the managers still don't understand why more experienced, but junior level, engineers (level 2 to 4) leave...
advice_management:
Read both pros and cons. 
Solutions to these problems are pretty obvious.

summary: "Exciting projects found within a monstrosity of a company"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 3 years
pros:
Work on some of the largest and most advanced defense contracts the DoD has awarded
Very flexible work schedule
9/80 schedule, i.e. every other Friday off is usually the "norm". Expect to work some off-Fridays though.
Vacation accrual, i.e. rollover hours between calendar years up to generous maximums
Paid overtime when working extra hours (has to be authorized, but that's usually pretty easy. Just 1x pay though, no time-and-a-half or anything)
Loss of contracts or proposal does not mean you will get laid off. The company does a great job of finding employees other work when projects close out.
Overall very friendly co-workers and some brilliant minds
One of the most demographically diverse environments I've ever worked, especially considering the engineering industry
Management is experienced and usually keeps the employee insulated from managerial nuisances
They will pay for your education with generous applications of "the rules" in your favor. I have never taken advantage myself, but I've heard so many great things about the "EdAssist" program I have to mention it.
cons:
Fairly average pay and benefits, nothing special. 401k match maxes out at 7% for new employees, if you contribute 8%.
Bonuses are only for top performers, based on your management performance review. They limit the recipients to ~10% at each level, so if you're new and below level 4 - good luck. Even if you get one, the amount is so small you don't even care to try the next year. I've seen about 3% of my gross salary one year when I was awarded the "top" level of review. Don't expect anything beyond your base salary.
Absolutely no company-sponsored extras, i.e. no work-related parties, no freebies, no perks, not even break rooms or TVs in their so-called flagship campus "Space Park" in Redondo Beach. This campus is a historical wonder, but a modern-day joke for such a large company to still be working in.
Enormous corporation (80,000+ employees) means you cannot even begin to understand the high-level management structure. You will see congratulatory emails about VIP-level promotions for people you have not only never heard of, but couldn't even figure out their role if you tried.
Almost all of NG's business is from government contracts, most of which are defense related and a large portion of those classified SCI (the biggest exception is probably James Webb Space Telescope) This means lots of overhead, red-tape and process bloat. Be prepared for a one-line software code change to take 6 months and cost $1 million. SIGH.
Business travel can be frequent, depending on your project. The business travel rules are nuts and an absolute nightmare to work though since you have to adhere to the government FAR regulations. Booking a short domestic trip can be way more trouble than necessary, especially when submitting expenses on the return.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Good pay.  Job security.
cons:
-Medical ins. is very lacking.  Expect to pay a lot out of pocket.
-A lot of people have to work 6 day work weeks continuously.
-No sick time allotted. It comes out of PTO so people tend to come in when they are sick.
-You will most likely not get to write software.
-If you get to do software, which is a BIG if, management cares more about lines of code and number of issues fixed rather than the quality of the product.
-You will most likely not get to write software (this needs to be said twice).
-Management will likely retaliate or ignore you if you say anything, leaving you hopeless.
-A lot of people are upset, leaving this campus with a very negative air about it
-Very poor planning and scheduling.
-There is a lot of fighting about how to do things because everyone wants to be the idea person; often the highest manager makes decisions based on their own personal opinion.
-I have heard managers yelling and being aggressive towards employees multiple times.
-Performance reviews are a joke.  They give reviews based on a curve rather than on actual performance.  That means you could be a top performer, but not get the rating because they didn't have any more "slots" open for top performers.
-No telecommuting.  I get that in some situation you can't but it still is a con as a lot of employers offer at least some degree of telecommuting.
advice_management:
Be honest with candidates about the ACTUAL work they will be doing.  Also, get over your position of power.  You hired engineers to help the company perform on contracts by being engineers.  Let us do that!

If you think my review is biased, take a look at the ratings trend on Glassdoor for this campus.  Or better yet, take a look at the attrition rates.  I can guarantee you they are high.  Word of advice: people leave bosses, not jobs.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: The salary is ok if you need a job but not great compensation.
cons: My assigned group was in chaos. There was a management transition happening and numerous employees in my group were unhappy. New management was making a lot of unpopular changes and new to the management position. When I started, there was no clear plan for my job assignments. I was open-minded so I was ok, but was often given tasking other employees no longer wanted. The level of work given well surpassed the level I was hired for. Also no relocation assistance was provided! This is a red-flag for a company being cheap or a sign of an unimportant job! I've always received relocation assistance in the past. I also received no cost of living increase. Just a basic 10% bump although the area I was relocating to had a higher cost of living and I was underpaid along with most new employees in my group. Advice- if you know you were/are underpaid in your previous/current job, reasonably boost your last salary  because HR gives little consideration. I only stayed for several months! Ironically, a family member had a bad experience with this same company in a totally different location! Future employee beware! This company is definitely sub par compared to its top competitors...
advice_management: Be careful of selecting employees to fill management roles who have no prior experience leading others.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros:
-9/80 flexible schedule
- have had the opportunity to work with some very smart people
- good rotation program for fresh college graduates
cons:
- I feel as though I have walked back in time, a very much boys club mentality. While the company is trying to change this, the core culture at BWI is still unfortunately the same despite efforts to change it. Every year it’s a new theme such as emphasis on feeling psychologically safe or open culture however these are just words without leading to much action or meaning. 
- there is no standardization of processes between various functions, manufacturing facilities within campus. There is a work around process for processes established by the company and cannot be easily found or understood.
- not great work / life balance.
- performance feedback system is heavily dependent upon your manager - whose reviews they incorporate vs whose they don’t, there is a lot of bias and favoritism.
- general culture at BWI, especially in the east bldg, is stressful, and demoralizing. You need to cater to every persons nuances , & quirks and their way of doing things  to get things. There is no established level of standard behavior that can be expected from people at this location. It’s the worst I have seen having worked at NG competitors.
- not a liberal company when it comes to the general population of people on campus, more close minded and not as diverse group of people.
advice_management:
BWI specific- there are some of you that truly do care for your employees and do what a manager is supposed to do which is guide you, mentor you, help you, back you up when needed and look out for you, genuinely, not just pretend or provide lip service.   Unfortunately, on this campus there is few and far between of you.

At the lower levels there is a lot of unfair treatment of employees based upon biases & preferences.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time

cons: Culture has been to promote by tenure without considering qualifications or capability. As a top hiring company for veterans, there's a lack of support and appreciation for reservists . main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: The mechanics, inspectors, leads and supervisors on the floor do not hesitate to stop what they are doing and lend a hand. Supervisors and leads are loyal to their crews, and even some of the project managers are too. Pay is good. Benefits are too.
cons: Site upper management (Lake Charles facility) has made a lot of policies and programs that get in the way of productivity (a lot, too), and they do nothing to improve or replace them with better solutions, despite suggestions from those on the floor.  Facility is a production turned maintenance facility, and many of the production practices are still attempted to be used to do maintenance, which is ineffective. Access to maintenance manuals is a pain. Be prepared to work a lot of O/T (but all aviation maintenance is like that. Not NG specific)
advice_management: Update your procedures on the floor to reflect the maintenance function of the site. Make the publications easier to get to (like .pdf). Remove programs that are ineffective and wasteful (like the current RFID tool crib) and replace them with something effective and less time consuming (bar codes, move the crib to a location where it is better suited).

summary: "Bullying, Bias, and Harassment by Management - Terrible Place to Work"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: The company is slow moving and behind the curve in terms of top talent and technology so it isn't as competitive as other companies
cons:
Abuse and bullying by certain managers. They prey on certain people that they just "dont like", micro manage the exact timing of when you arrive at work and literally bar certain people from taking sick days (but not others = discrimination) ! I overheard a manager tell an employee that she didn't like (for no reason) that this employee could not call in sick and had to "suck it up". There is gross discrimination that goes on here, where certain people are "allowed" flexibility at work if they have kids but if you don't have kids and are younger they have different expectations from you. If you aren't liked you might be subject to gossip and people making things up about you/blaming you for things you didn't do. It's all pretty standard over at NG San Jose. Overall, management is completely incompetent and they are lucky that they haven't had any lawsuits on their hands given the gross display of bias, harassment, bullying, and otherwise irrational pursuits of certain employees for absolutely no logical reason while employees watch in shock and horror. Meanwhile, HR doesn't care and their attitude is that managers can make up their own rules and do whatever they want.

Meanwhile in Silicon Valley all the Facebook and Googlers have tons of flexibility, benefits, way more pay...this company is the worst of the worst of the worst.
advice_management: The advice that I have to managers in my department would be to leave, because what you are doing is unethical, probably not legal, and emotionally detrimental and damaging to people that work under you.

summary: "Good for resume, not so good for decent pay increases"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Having Northrop Grumman on my resume as my first job out of college is essentially the ticket to job security in any software field I go into. The well-respected company name is great and recognized by pretty much everyone. Even if you choose to stay at the company, you pretty much have a job here for life. The company is never running out of government contracts and projects, and it feels like we're constantly hiring.
cons: The pay is average. If you're in CS, then the pay is actually under market standard. The pay increases per year are small - anywhere from 2-3%. Management makes a lot of excuses for why it's taking you so many years to go up to the next level, even though you meet all the requirements. People are constantly leaving my project for this reason (low salary). They just come work here for the experience for 2-3 years and then leave. The management actually doesn't mind this because it means that they can keep project costs low by always hiring new grads who are ready to take the low salary. But it definitely means that the projects go at a slow pace because we are constantly training new hires.
advice_management: Work harder to get your employees up to the next level, particularly when they deserve it.

summary: "Some insights into getting the job and whats required"
job_title: Current Employee - Systems Engineering and Test Integration IV
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Good pay,  The best in Technology
cons:
The security clearance process is a total pain in the a**,  takes up to 2 years to get a TS clearance.  If your interim clearance gets denied watch out...  your offer can be pulled anytime. They wont hold your job for 2 years and wont tell you this up front - leaving you up in the air, so don't  quit your current job unless you get interim clearance otherwise the door will slam in your face with one foot in the door...

This company lives and dies by the contracts,  they over hire in many cases and expect a certain percentage to fail their clearance contingency so don't get your hopes up until you get the formal approval to walk in the door....
advice_management: Keep those contracts rolling in.....   and don't slam the door on those new hires before they can step inside

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Some really nice people to work with, interesting work. good cafeteria.
cons: Horrible middle management, ZERO safety culture (they claim they value safety but their actions don't show it), the labs don't have any of the necessary tools to do your job, yet alone safety equipment.  If you ever speak up and voice your opinion, expect to not get far in the organization.  Some very toxic software people who think yelling is an acceptable form of communication.  The cost of a security clearance and how long it takes to get them, make it unappealing to fire lazy, toxic, or incompetent people.    Expect to work 70+ hours with little appreciation, working you endlessly to meet deadlines because software ran over their deadlines, or no hardware, or someone took your hardware to use in their program, and then only to have your program cut.    Vacation was a joke.  They rolled vacation, sick days, personal days into PTO (Paid time off) so that means everyone goes to work sick.  They won't negotiate PTO even if you come with lots of external experience.   Do yourself a favor and read the reviews people post about this place, they are true.
advice_management: Listen to your employees, hire managers that line up with company values/ fire the one's that are ineffective, promote safety and make it a priority, give more PTO.  Lots of companies offer at least a sick day.  Don't make it seem like since you get 9/80 fridays off we get something for free.

summary: "This place will exponentially drain your life away like the machine in the movie The Princess Bride!"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros:
- Innovative projects/programs
- Good coworkers
- Decent benefits
- multiple locations

HR has a stellar reputation for conflict resolution.
cons:
- Horrible middle management. They are given full decision making autonomy while rarely being held accountable. If you're hired on to a program or project team with this type of questionable leadership, you are doomed. 

- Zero work/life balance. At the direction of senior managent to cut cost, deliver on spec, and on schedule, middle management grossly under hires the required number of personnel for teams while utilizing the "do more with less" mentality. Subsequently, programs have extremely high turnover rates due to employee burnout and being multi-tasked to accomplish several different jobs that you weren't hired for.

- Almost zero employee investment. #2 defense contractor.  They could careless if you stay in the same position 2 years or 20 years. There are many employees that work 12+ hour days then turn around and are forced to seek higher certifications or training on their own limited free time.

- Communication flow only exists between corporate and middle management. "The less the worker bees know the easier they are to control" methodology.  Management won't teach you a thing about the company or their processes. If you want to understand what goes on within the company you'll spend countless hours surfing the internal websites trying to figure things out on your own.
advice_management:
- Hold middle management accountable. 
- Constantly promoting managers from within leads to stifled ideas, poor management (Yes men), and a lack of diversity.
- Force programs to take the time and train their people. Quarterly webcasts are not enough and should not take the place for lower management employee communication.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros:
Pros:  
Excellent co workers - some of the people you work with are some of the best in the nation.  A pure pleasure to work with.
Interesting work - Again, some of the most interesting work in the nation.
cons:
Cons:
Done def management once again.  Currently in the few years I have worked there, the upper management has changed approx. 3 times.  The lower level management isn't some of the best either.  They choose GREAT engineers with zero or no leadership skills and absolutely ZERO training, of course the obvious happens, leadership that tries to only make decisions that they will not get any heat from.    All the  employees are essentially thrown under the bus.  
The initial salary is okay, the raises are between 2-3%.  So far they are starting to cut anybody who higher than average salaries or even average salaries.

Moving packages are just plain dumb.  15k to move to a new place with little.  The company they use is, check this out, a subsidiary of Northrop, so they charge a premium to move your stuff to themselves, never mind the company is crap  and a half.  

PTO.... yea, when the hurricane came, they tried to make the people use their own PTO  for the forced plant closure. 

 What your specialty is may not guarantee you actually doing it.  MANY people are doing something totally different that what they are hired to do.  They did this with my manager and that person stayed 1 year to the day to finish out the contact and then moved on.   So the current procedure is to put you in a department where you have zero skill in, grade you as if you do know.  Many older engineers are just leaving.
advice_management: Why don't you listen or at least pay attention to your the "anonymous"s yearly reviews you make us take.  PS... I have seen people get questioned and pushed out for these reviews.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Great work/life balance. Rarely had to work over 40 hours a week. Options to work remotely.

Good job security.  It’s very difficult to lose your job here.
cons:
Yearly raises and promotion increases are very low (0-3%), advancement opportunities are limited.  Management does not like to promote internally.  As a result of the very low raises and rare promotions, you will fall way behind in market value the longer you stay at NG. There is no compensation beyond your base salary. No bonuses, profit-sharing, RSUs, or any other incentives exist for technical employees.

Very poor environment and antiquated, old-school work culture. The company is a throwback to the 20th century.  Lab equipment is ancient and software is always numerous versions/iterations behind. Slow to adopt new technology and refuse to make capital expenditures on necessary test equipment. Office building and company culture are straight out of the 1980s. Very few employees under 40, most of the workforce are elderly and near retirement. This is not the place to be if you’re looking to work with cutting edge technology in a modern work environment.
advice_management: Make an effort to retain good employees instead of just mass hiring. Aerospace and defense companies will continue to have staffing issues until they stop lowballing technical staff.

summary: "A good job for someone who is happy taking a big paycheck home for little work."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Company name is strong in the market right now. You are valued much more highly outside of the company with NG experience. 

The people are generally nice and friendly. 

Management is keen on addressing employee concerns. Lots of surveys and employee feedback efforts. 

"Business" casual attire which means casual at NGC

Pay is higher than most other companies.
cons:
Work is not challenging at all, especially for entry level positions. Even if you are capable and willing of taking on more challenging work, they don't have enough work to go around. They recruit individuals with high GPAs and strong academic backgrounds just to sit in cubes and surf the Internet. 

There is a large retiring population that is heavily compensated for doing very little work. It is demoralizing for younger employees that senior professionals just come into work to collect a paycheck. 

Nepotism is everywhere, especially in entry level hiring (intern/PDP). Most everyone is related to someone. 

Tuition assistance is nothing like it used to be. Lots of fancy verbiage used to sugarcoat the program so that a lot of entry level professionals are incentivized to work for the company.

Lots of office gossip and backbiting. Directors can be overheard gossiping about other employees. 

The work culture is very boring. Everyone wants to get in early, work through lunch, and then leave as early as possible. The company promotes this culture with another perk- 9/80 fridays. The reason people love it so much is because literally no one wants to be at work.
advice_management: Don't hire smart people to do unchallenging work or they will leave. Atleast try to get involved with younger professionals and see if work can be reallocated to those that are sitting around waiting for it. It is very demoralizing for younger employees to experience a culture where most senior employees don't care about their jobs, just their paychecks.

summary: "Finally - a job where I really fit ... and make a difference!"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: I have worked at a number of companies, large and small across Albuquerque. From small local companies to large corporations and large government contractors. Northrop Grumman's Albuquerque group has been the best move I've ever made. There is tremendous room to learn and grow here (within certain limits--it is ABQ, not DC) and the support from management is amazing. The expectations  here are high. Hard work, high quality and innovation are expected. But the rewards are great. The pay and benefits are some of the best in NM and the team is fantastic. I've worked with wonderful, talented people at other jobs, but the group of people working at Northrop Grumman are truly a cut above -- not just in Albuquerque, but across the company. Very happy to be working here.
cons: There are very few cons. I've heard of slightly better 401k matching at some places, but it's still very competitive. I've had cheaper insurance coverage elsewhere, but prices are rising everywhere (and the options here give you several affordable plans to choose from to suit your family situation). It is a large defense company, so some things move slowly and there are some restrictions due to tight security, but even with that, the local management finds ways to innovate and find solutions to solve issues. Overall I don't have much to complain about.
advice_management: It's hard to manage work in a competitive, contract-based environment. Juggling dozens of projects and dozens of resources can be difficult. Balancing the needs of customers, the business and the team is critical -- keep fine-tuning that balance and you'll continue to get stellar results!

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The mission at NGC is ultimately to protect the United States, and this creates a shared sense of purpose and urgency. In general the facilities are well stocked with necessary equipment. The people are friendly and helpful.
cons: NGC puts people in mid-level management positions that have no desire or skill to be a manager. These people are also expected to continue to perform a technical job at the same time. The review process affects your raise with a numerical rating system, but the system is so poorly defined that managers can rank anyone based on personal preference instead of performance.
advice_management: Take the time to develop a plan with your employees about what they want at a job. Don't put people with no social skills in leadership positions.

Schedule is pretty good with the 9/80 and flexible hours.
cons:
Little to no upward growth opportunities.
Promotions seem to be based on the "Good ol Boy" system instead of merit.
I have received no guidance from my management on expectations they have for me with the program, or what I need to do stand-out. 
There is next to no training, for positions... it is expected to hit the ground running.
Management seems disconnected from the workers, and tries to make up for it by micromanaging every situation.
advice_management:
Stop Micro-management!
Make a conscious effort to be there for your employees when they come to you for career advice, and mentorship. 
Provide at least an introductory training for a new position, instead of letting the employee flouder about and burn countless off-duty hours to try and understand their position.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than 10 years
pros: 9/80 work week  Does have a tight screening process on hiring employees - so work force is well qualified. Does have and use training budget - so an employee can learn certain skills.
cons: Eliminated pension in 2008.  Has a 401K plan that is not very employee frriendly.  People hired pre-2008 can get a company match of 4%, but have to contribute 10% of their salary to get the Northrop 4%.  People hired after 2008 get a 6% match, but conditions are also hard to meet in order to get the full 6%.  Matching conditions are not easily discoverable.  Raise pool over time has become very unfriendly to employees.  Performance appraisal process is not connected to salary.  Employees get ranked based on how they meet their goals.  Then the company decides on a yearly basis what percentage of employees need to be ranked as Level 5, 4, 3 or 2.  Level 5 employees can get a decent raise, even in the 10% range.  But about 1/2 of the employees get a 0% raise - because so many people have to be ranked Level 3.  Then the salary decides what raise the person gets - if the employee makes over the mid-point salary of the employee grouping, the raise is likely to be 0% for all Level 3 employees.  This is incredibly demotivating for employees: they can work hard, meet or exceed all of their goals, and still get a 0% raise.  Years ago the company implemented a policy that disallows brining personal plants to the office - to eliminate using Northrop water for a personal plant.  Benefits costs are skyrocketing as the company tries to eliminate money it spends on employee benefts.  However, Northrop is truly a 1% company.  Executives are treated much differenty than non-management.  VPs and above receive large salary increases, as well as bonuses - while ~50% of the normal people get 0%.  Over years, the company has eliminated many grade levels - making it very difficult to get promoted.  It is a good company to work at for 2 - 3 years, but not for 10 or more.
advice_management: Management insists that limiting large raises to Level 5 employees is good - becaise it motvates people to try hard to be a Level 5.  However, the percetage of Level 5 employees is too small and the common circumstance is that the employee works very hard, meets all goals, but can't crack the Level 5 group because there are so few of them.  And the employee gets a 0% raise.  Management claims not to think that this demotivates hard workers.  But managemet does not talk to the affected workers to get their views.  Management needs to understand that it cannot continue to take things away from the workers, and still expect them to be as dedicated as the company wants them to be

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: Job security is not a concern, as long as you're not a terrible employee who causes problems. Some of the projects can be very rewarding and challenging. Some of the management personnel do a great job of not micromanaging.
cons:
Northrup Grumman career advancement is mediocre at best as it is not determined by your impact, it's how big of bragging rights do you bring your manager on *their* résumé. 

Northrup Grumman salaries, at least at my site, are not great compared to competition. One of the not-so-brilliant incentives Northrup Grumman has employed for ages is a bonus.. that you get in 3 years.. maybe. Basically, if the company does well, you get the bonus in x years. But the criteria for what determines if you get the bonus is not concrete, just ".. if Northrup Grumman does well..". In addition, you are sometimes competing against engineers that you'll never see, because they are not on site.. so prepare to not do as well as you'd expect because somebody somewhere that you've never met is better than you.

Due to the above point, Northrup Grumman has started letting in talent that would not be employed in past times. But since the salaries are not the best, the talent musts suffer. 

At the beginning of the year I strongly recommend taking a long vacation that goes well into January. If not, you'll be left stranded with no authorization to work as functional management and project management fight over who should be paying you during this "transition period". HINT: Neither end up paying you in my experience, so just avoid the headache and take an extended vacation.
advice_management: Trend towards flexibility again. As little as 3 years ago, there was tremendous flexibility between management and employee pertaining to working holidays, different hours, remote, etc. That is trickling away.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Super relaxed schedule. You work 9-80's and often times you can flex it if you want to take an extra day off or what not. Supporting production means overtime hours (though not at overtime rate) is pretty easy to come by. You meet some really nice people and work with many great individuals. Good horizontal movement if you want to try different roles (at least in the Aerospace Sector).
cons:
Large companies are too bureaucratic. It takes way too long to get anything done (which can be a blessing and a curse depending on your personality). Older folks in the company do not like change and is really hard for someone starting out to restructure a process or make improvements. Poor vertical movement. Good luck promoting haha. 

ALSO, if you get an offer and the HR tells you that there is no cap to the reimbursement program for their masters program - do not listen to them as it is only partially true. The education reimbursement program is a joke. If you want to get something outside of your technical scope of responsibilities, it will not get approved. If you want more money to cover your expenses, you will need to get VP signature which is near impossible.
advice_management:
Cut the red tape. The chain of approval is too long, and by the time it gets to the big boss on top, he hardly even knows what the approval is for anyways.

Direct advice to my manager: exercise inclusion and promote a healthy work environment. There are good days and bad days, but if you react negatively to all the bad news - it can be really demoralizing for your team.

cons: Women are not treated equally. Most managers cannot do programming so they chose to be managers. They won't be able to understand if you are facing a software problem and tend to blame the problems on you. The managers that are good technically tend to stay on the same project for a long time and forget how it feels to be on a new project. summary: "Working in Supply Chain is a nightmare"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros:
9/20 schedule
Tuition assistance 
Clean work environment
Employee resource groups
Parking 
Working computers
They want me to add 20 words of pros but to be honest it's hard to find that many pros for this place.
cons:
I thought I had gotten the opportunity of a lifetime only to find out it was all a sham. Working in the supply chain dept at the Spectrum Center in San Diego is a living nightmare. Very toxic environment!
The managers are the worst I have ever seen. They lie to your face, promote backstabbing and gossip among employees. You can't complain to HR because they are friends with the managers and will make sure you never get promoted or able to move depts. You will only get promoted if managers like you regardless of experience, education or work performance. Preferential treatment is at all time high. Just suck up to that lazy manager and you get your way. If you aren't one of the favorites you might as well leave because your career and salary will come to a halt. 
The turnover is the highest I've seen,  PAs are always going out on disability or quitting but the managers don't care they can always fill the positions with contract labor. The managers have all gotten the positions because they are friends with the bosses wife or some else, they bring nothing to the table while sitting in their offices trolling their phones all day. 
PAs get blamed for pretty much everything when things go wrong. We are the punching bag of other departments. Programs don't realize it's a tough job pleasing programs and compliance and when you have unproductive lazy managers life is very hard. The processes and procedures PAs have to work with are so outdated it's unbelievable for a company this size. Sucking up to compliance is what PAs have to do all day every day for no apparent real reason. 
I have never been so stressed at work in my entire life and can't wait to find a new job like everyone else.
advice_management: I beg higher management to really take a look at the managers toxic behavior and stop promoting managers with departments  that have high turnover rates. Please hire managers with real life experience and that can bring real value and positive change to this organization. Gens and Millennials will not tolerate this kind of work environment and will leave.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: Northrop Grumman is a very stable company to work for. They offer good benefits and are present in several major cities. They also have a solid funding source, the government.
cons: During my employment with NG I did not see much of a growth path. There are too many levels of management and the salaries are usually lower than the industry.
advice_management: Stop shrinking the benefits, fix or drop the "engagement" plans, pay competitively, flatten the  organization, expand to serve clients outside of the government.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: As with any company if you are at the HQ you are where the action is
cons: Lots and lots of bureaucracy.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than 3 years
pros: The benefits are really good. It's a good place to start if you have no experience and want to work in defense contracting
cons: The culture is too old and toxic for young professionals. Terrible engineering practices and the work you do will set you back 30 years. The pay is some of the lowest I've seen across similar companies as well. Management has a bias toward hiring people from their small private college, and most higher managers all come from said unknown private college
advice_management: Don't let your biases run the company. Half of the people I have met from the school are very under-qualified and should not be the engineers getting promoted. These are important projects, let those who know what they are doing take over.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Really difficult to find something positive.  Talent + for the one place to list employee career goals.  Now if management and talent acquisition would use this tool correctly to move employees around within the company like they should.
cons:
Benefit cuts.  Used to be 8% for a 401k match.  Dropped to 4%.  Healthcare skyrocketed.

More and more tasks were added to job jar.  Workers neither compensated or recognized for added tasks outside of job description.  Performing multiple jobs and only paid for one.

Talent Acquisition (TA) is woefully unskilled at finding talent within the company for placement in other positions.  Zero assistance or placement provided to skilled employees with varied backgrounds and degrees.  

Severe lack of communication from management at all levels.  Same issues are addressed yearly by a survey and nothing ever changes.
advice_management: Communication is vital in a team environment.  Engage with your employees instead of making them feel like just another insignificant number.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: It's a job. Hard to get fired. Nice 401K matching.
cons: Other than 401K, poor benefits. Not very accommodating for families or work schedule. Management is atrocious.
advice_management: Go work at Walmart.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: great pay, supportive, and excellent managers
cons: have no cons I can think of.
advice_management: none

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: If you love the work you do, this is the perfect place for you.
cons: Management is terrible.  They behave nicely to you to your face and turn around and stab you in the back.  I was constantly stressed out and left as soon as my one year commitment was up.
advice_management: If you're going to have a conversation with your employee, it should be between you and your employee, not you, your employee, and 3 other people, especially when it comes to performance reviews.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year

cons: compensation is lacking, the gender gap is real. Salary is mis-defined, as all hours worked need to be accounted for, the company constantly encourages employees to work overtime if on salary, but if you happen to go under on hours you are required to use vacation hours. bonuses are near impossible to receive.
advice_management: compensate employees better. improve work-life balance.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Pay is great. Most of the people are great.
cons: very top heavy company, too many assistant managers, assistants for assistant managers. Honestly seems more important to be able to convey a problem to the customer than to be able to fix the problem. Some people will do just about anything to advance it is sometimes disturbing.
advice_management: Please retain skilled technicians,  there is a big difference between experienced troubleshooters who fix complex problems and technicians who are not troubleshooters. I notice a lot of ppl tell management they knew how to fix issues after the issue is solved by someone else.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: Large company benefits in terms of vacation, health care, corporate discounts, corporate policies. The technical work can be very interesting at times. There are still many excellent technical people in the workforce. Engineering/designing work can be very flexible in terms of hours.
cons: Large company bureaucracy, politics and nonsense in general. Engineering has been superseded by management and politics. Engineers have to move into management in order to move up the food chain. A pure engineering/technical career is fast becoming a dead end.
advice_management: Customers pay for products which ultimately comes from engineering. Management is supposed to support engineering, not dictate it. Value your engineering team more.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year

summary: "Has the bones to be a good corporation, but lacks the leadership at the mid and senior level"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Stable industry with new large contracts. Flexible work schedules that allow for offsite work days.
cons: Poor management, among the worth that I have seen. Low employee morale as people feel they are over worked and not appreciated.
advice_management: Stop placing managers in positions they have no experience in. Ensure they listen to their employees. Train managers to develop  and lead-not micro manage.

summary: "Good place to start, but not friendly to those with "outside the box" thinking."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Steady work if you're not in a contract.  Great benefits.
cons: Extremely conservative and non-innovative corporate culture.  If you don't fit the traditional corporate mold, kiss your chances of advancement goodbye. HR makes promotions, raises, and bonuses a mess unless you know the right people. Management tends to be 45+ that view employees as assets to be used and abused as the business dictates. Young, innovative, and outside-the-box thinking is discouraged at best, punished at worst.
advice_management: Get with the times. Employees are not assets. Treat talent as they deserve to be treated, or they will be looking elsewhere once a better offer comes. Provide opportunities for advancement and growth for non-engineers. Don't view younger employees (those 40 or younger) as tools to be exoloited until they get fed up and leave.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than 10 years

advice_management: Management needs to help the employee that the ex-spouse is abusing at work

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros:
- Great colleagues; they love their own occupation and staff is very friendly and understanding when being a rookie and getting used to the daily system rhythm there. 
- I learn something different every day 
- Dedication and hard work, merit is highly praised recognized.
- They're strong advocates of skill enrichment and have already been on travel 3 times withing my 1st year as a Full-time Employees.
- I started out as a Contractor for 7 months, and then turned Full-time.
cons: Nothing negative, I love working for Northrop Grumman. I love the respect that they have for our troops and veterans. Everyone is respectful that I've encountered so far.
advice_management: Cross-pollinate with our sister stations and switch up the norm. Allow us to shadow each other from time to time.

advice_management: I honestly never tried, or cared, but I would assume that it is possible and wouldn't be that hard.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than a year

cons: A hands off style of mentoring interns. Many times I found myself without knowing who to go to for questions or what my next task was.
advice_management: Make sure each internship has a definite goal and set of requirements, including a designated mentor who the intern can go to for questions and guidance.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: Helpful and supportive direct management.  Generally work with friendly peers.  If you are looking for a stable job to put in 40 hour weeks with great job security this is a good fit.
cons: Growth opportunities (both financially and professionally) are mostly below average.  The culture is not very positive and no one really likes their job.  Upper management can treat more junior employees disrespectfully.  Because of the job stability, poor processes, and lack of incentive to perform well employees don't always try their best.
advice_management: Usually a generally negative work environment, lack of growth opportunities, and an "old school" work culture contributes to unmotivated employees whose main motivation is to stick to status quo until they can find something better.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than 5 years

cons: There are no cons to place here
advice_management: The immediate managers are in the trenches. Whomever gets Greg Nemeth as a supervisor is getting the cream of the crop.  He is concerned for your future, growth and development and will do everything in his power to help you excel. He gives autonomy while giving attention and is extremely professional, easy to work with and super knowledgeable in the area of Quality. He is an impressive supervisor and Quality Professional and I wish I could take him with me in my future endeavors. I learned a lot from him and no longer working for him saddens me greatly.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Stability, due to US and UK Navy contracts that could last 40+ years.  The origional contract was to update the entire missile launcher systems for the new submarines.  However, the military budgets were reduced so much that only minor upgrades are affordable.  In other words, this is boring.
cons: Operates like a big jobshop, facilities here are ancient, dating back to 1906, and are unhealthy!  Does not meet modern codes.
advice_management: Advance senior people with experience rather than mostly inexperienced kids and minorities. I know the Navy is concerned that the average age is high, so the present work force will retire before the end of the program.  However, they are rushing to transfer the know how, and the kids are not yet ready.  Also, many resign to take more advanced hi-tech experience.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: The work schedule is very flexible (for the groups I've been in). 9/80 work schedule is available, and you can flex your day off around as needed. Good education reimbursement (although they have recently started restricting it). Paid overtime, even for salaried employees. Aging workforce means plenty of opportunities for moving up.
cons: Benefits have been shrinking recently (health, school, etc). The bureaucracy can be difficult to deal with sometimes, "the easiest part of the job is designing the radar" implying completing all the paperwork is harder (radars aren't that easy to design!)

advice_management: Don't try to deceive your employees just because you have a job rec that desperately needs to be filled. Offer more pay to employees in high cost living areas.

summary: "Client Opportunities are Interesting//Annual Review Process is Horrible"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Company has many Contracts, which enables employees to join new Programs to enhance job skills and reduce boredom of being on the same Project for many years.

Truly some very smart people dedicated to the their government customer's mission.  You can serve on a Program that clearly has positive implications to our country's national defense.
cons: Annual review process is so awkward and employees are required to finalize their annual review at least two months before the year ends.  Also, way too much emphasis on Innovation from a Company standpoint--e.g. how many people did you refer or how much did you grow the business--rather than how employees have developed and implemented innovative solutions for their government customers.
advice_management:
Distribute the majority of Contract Award fees among the employees on the Contract who worked so hard to generate the high rating.
Switch the focus from Shareholders, Customers, and Employees to Employees, Customers, and Shareholders.  Happy Employees lead to happy Customers which ultimately lead to happy Shareholders.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Challanging work, good pay. Friendly coworkers.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Infusion of new, young talent has been invigorating to the company.  Most of the employees are motivated to do a good job and most teams have a driven personality to accomplish the stated goals of the team(s).
cons: Upper management has taken to being more concerned about short term shareholder value and the sector/business areas goals are significantly slanted to that.  The new business philosophy has  put a strain on the relationship between the company and their customer(s).  Although the young talent has been invigorating to the business, upper management wants those younger employees to become the managers now and replace the older managers (read more expensive but certainly more experienced) to the detriment of the projects/programs involved.
advice_management: For the business sectors to be able to execute their contracts successfully, sector management needs to be more flexible in the approach to be able to execute the contracts to the customers high satisfaction (i.e., IPARs and CPARS).

summary: "Great company to work for.  Benefits could be better."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Northrop tries hard to keep employees working on jobs that interest them.  They also support continuous self-improvement.  A heavy emphasis on internal promotions provides a clear path for career growth.
cons: Benefits could be better compared to other employers in the same industry.  They are not bad, however.  A few are improvements over other employers I know of such as the 401k matching.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Easy to move within the company
cons: Hard to advance in some contracts

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 3 years
pros: Well known and respected company. Huge amount of jobs in many fields, but mostly focused on engineering and IT. Very competitive benefits package and salaries. My particular job was very flexible, letting me work from home at least 2-3 days per week.
cons: Can be a bit stereotypically "corporate" sometimes. Tons of forms and hurdles for any request. Many different layers of HR.
advice_management: Strive to be more personal. Have larger salary bonuses for high job performance. Stay on top of subcontractors to make sure they hire the most qualified applicants.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 10 years
pros: Corporation says the right things, leads in a wonderful way, and is aware of the current world we live in. I love the work schedule. What we do really does matter.
cons: The local leadership seems at times not to understand what is going on with the company. Percentages for wage raises and who gives them and how they are truly earned is like trying to understand an ancient dialect at times. Accountability at our site needs to be raised as well. Career opportunities for hourly or non-degree individuals is all but absent.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Great people and great job
cons: none right now but time will tell

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
When there is work - i.e. contracts have been obtained, work can be interesting, although unionized manufacturing is sometime problematic for getting things accomplished.
Benefits reasonable, but are reducing as time goes by.
cons: When work is limited, employees can be laid off with short notice, and there is a widely held perception that ageism is behind many layoffs or strong hints that retirement might be beneficial.
advice_management: Treat customers with respect and provide requested support. Hearing foreign customers complain the this company is the most difficult contractor to deal with is not likely to make for employee loyalty. Claimed culture and values not apparent in some cases

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than 3 years

cons: bureaucracy, requires security clearance for best jobs

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Northrop Grumman promotes work/life balance and management genuinely cares about their employees. This is a company that lets  you choose your career path.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great place to work for a recent college graduate, job was slow pace. Staff was always friendly and willing to train on any issues. Software had funny quotes and comments when you would open it every time.  When software would crash after working on (or newly opened) received funny quotes ("It's all fun and games until you lose an eye"  "Don't run with scissors you may hurt yourself" "If it is not on paper, it does not count").  Good exposure to work with great engineers and project management team.  Good place to work, personally not interested in type of work.  Clean office.  Would highly recommend to a new college graduate.
cons: Need to spread out work on projects more evenly between staff.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time

cons: Feels too many level of management.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

summary: "So far I have enjoyed working here."

summary: "Good company but pay is not competitive"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Northrop Grumman is a solid company. Their primary business (funding) is contract based, mostly with the government.
cons: Pay is not competitive in many markets compared to other companies. We a contract ends, so does your position.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

cons: Like most companies, nothing will be handed to you. Promotions aren't doled out easily, need to fight for yourself.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Very ethical company.  Decent medical benefits.  Good management structure.  Interesting work.  Year end week shutdown.
cons: Below average pay.  Lots of work (a.k.a. long hours).  Facilities are not the best.  Very limited vacation and holidays (other than the year end shutdown)
advice_management: Keep doing what you are doing.  Government contractor business is a very tough business.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

casual workplace

salary and benefits
friendly work place

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

summary: "Great pay and benefits. Management isn't that great."

advice_management: Should keep the competent people instead of laying them off and hiring new college graduates who don't have a lot of experience.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

the company has awesome benefits
every location ive visited fosters a great work environment
management and execs are extremely supportive of career advancement

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 5 years

cons: Sometimes communication between Aerospace and Technical Services isn't the best. I'm on a relatively new program so things are still being developed and sometimes there is resistance to change if a more efficient way to do something is developed.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than a year
pros: Opportunity for career growth since there are so many divisions, locations and products. Nice benefits package (at the time I was there). (My) Senior Managers were great mentors and supporters of my career path.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Competitive compensation package if employed for 3 years.
cons: Large company and you could easily get lost in the shuffle.
advice_management: Take care of employees.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: They paid a good salary and have decent benefits.  The work was challenging.
cons: It is a huge corporation, so you will not have any personal interactions with the upper management.  Your id is an number not a name.  There is no personal perks like company picnics or the like on a regular basis.
advice_management: When the customer contract is about end, please do the footwork and look for other opportunities for your employees.  Please do not give folks two weeks after a contract ends to find another position and then lay them off.  The footwork should have been done months in advance.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years

advice_management: Invest in at-work training - not just tuition pay (gee, thanks for letting me work all night every night - after working all day - to get better at the job you pay me to do!)

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Waning.  Very little positive to speak of any longer.
cons: They are practicing age discriminatory polices and getting away with it.  Giving merit increases to the just out of college crowd and not to people who have served the company for decades.  All of a sudden (after decades with the company and multiple managers) you just aren't quite cutting it any longer.  I would recommend to all newcomers to look very carefully at what management is doing there.
advice_management: Sell the company back to the employees and leave town.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 10 years

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 10 years
pros: Great culture, great people!  Constantly seeking to improve engagement as a company and leadership seeks to provide opportunities for interested employees.
cons: Levels are often based on years of experience over other qualities.  This has been changing over time as they work to give more and more stretch opportunities to less experienced employees.
advice_management: Keep it up.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: With the B-21 contract, it has become more stable and the stock price is rising.
cons: Management is short-sighted and does not value experience. They underpay their best people in order to drive them away and replace them with cheaper interns and level 1 engineers who don't have the necessary skills. Many have gone to Boeing for 20%-30% more pay. Management demonstrates no leadership, lies frequently, takes no personal interest in employees, and cares only about their own bottom lines. That's from first-level supervisors all the way up.
advice_management: Talk is cheap. Don't merely give lip service about valuing employees. That song is old and tired.

summary: "Stretched thin but they do take care of us."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
•Enjoy what I do as an engineer immensely.
•9/80 work schedule is absolutely embraced and appreciated.
cons:
•Minimal work space. Most, if not all, engineers at this location are forced to share work spaces. This is not conducive to high productivity.
•Team work amongst all employees, especially peer engineers, can be improved upon.
•Support from management is needed beyond the daily "how are you doing" routine.
advice_management:
•Need to improve bonus structure and annual raises to be distributed to those of us deserving, not just upper management.
•Managers need to anticipate project deadlines and request overtime approval in advance.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than 8 years
pros: Northrop Grumman is a well established company, and as such has a high quality infrastructure. I never had any doubts about for what the company stands, nor did I ever hesitate to put my name on any product or service provided to the customer. I really appreciated the fact that all documentation was kept up to date and accurate; a necessity in the work I was doing for them.
cons: While the contract to which I gave 8 years of my lie was small in comparison to other NG contracts, I was still working for a huge company. Consequently, I was nothing more than an employee number. When the contract was terminated, the people were just abandoned with a shrug of the shoulder. None of us ever felt like we meant anything to them.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Good benefits, time off, and decent pay.
cons: The same cons of any big company, the VPs and CEO are about the "big picture" and the bottom line and forget about taking care of their employees sometimes. They wait for people to retire or leave before finding a replacement and then lose a lot of valuable knowledge in the process. "do more with less" is becoming a common phrase.
advice_management: This is mainly for upper management since middle management has their hands tied frequently. Hire replacements NOW. Stop waiting for people to walk out the door before you put a req in for a new hire. It makes the rest of our lives much much harder

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: The company does have good benefits and the pay is at or above industry levels.
cons: In the division, and specifically the department that I work in, it is truly unbelievable how much management does not know about the job function that they are managing. There is no career progression, there are no promotions, there is no listening to constructive feedback and the philosophy is you can be replaced by a person with a lower salary who won't ask questions. It is even comical that they have actually stated that employee engagement rating scores that are significantly below industry norms (red) are good. I guess employees are now to believe that red is the new blue (high ratings).
advice_management: Be willing to listen to workers, look around at the personnel attrition rate, think about how to improve processes, get buy-in from workers and realize that the only reason you are there is to manage the work force to obtain the companies goals. Without trained, competent resources (personnel) it will become impossible for you to be considered a success.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

cons: Northrop is not a "cutthroat" company, meaning once an employee gets a job, they typically won't let go of him unless he has done something extremely wrong. This causes laziness in the work place and several people working on a job that could be done with less people. Northrop is also very bureaucratic, making it sometimes impossible to get simple jobs done.
advice_management: Make employees more accountable for mistakes they've made. Before all the older employees retire, make sure their lessons learned are passed down to the next generation of employees.

cons:
Benefits have declined a bit over time, and new employees are offered a bit less.
Frustrating corporate bureaucracy - shared services (payroll, HR, IT, etc) are accountable to no one and act like it - some good people in there, are some not-so-good.
SCA employees get less benefits.

For many years, this has been a great place to spend a career. More recently, this quality seems to have declined, with many moving on due to various frustrations.
advice_management: Maintain strong ethics. Provide direction from the top down.. don't pass the hard decisions down to the rank and file and hope they just 'deal with it'.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than 3 years
pros: Excellent benefits to include affordable, comprehensive medical plans, 401k investments matched up to 6%, access to education with a high annual cap on education spending, opportunity to travel for business and personnel development, outstanding managers, promote from within, acknowledge achievement in personnel (even award cash bonuses).  Opportunities for advancement, and tons of positions to apply for all over the world.
cons: Leaving this company was not easy.  My contract ended, and I couldn't find a follow-on within the company before my last day.  Rather than lay me off (which is what would typically happen in that situation), they told me I had to resign.  They did not offer any form of severance, and I did not receive my final pay check until the end of the pay cycle (CA state law says I should have received it within 48 hours of my final shift worked), also in that 2 weeks my 401k took about a 10% hit because of market fluctuation, so it really cost me a lot of money to leave NG.

Promotions are politically driven within a "good ol' boy network." summary: "Great if you find your niche or want a 9 to 5, mediocre if you are ambitious/innovative/think different."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
Salary, benefits (although theses are eroded every couple years). Like any company, if you manage to find your technical niche or a good team, things can be pretty awesome. 

Great for folk in areas that don't feel compelled to innovate through bureaucracy or just want a 9 to 5.  If you see yourself as an "idea person" that doesn't want to dig into the details, you'll fit in great. Decent starting out point for a career after which you'll get bored in 3 to 5 years. Many opportunities to advance given high attrition.
cons:
A tall and inverted management pyramid. Poor communication at all levels, information withholding. Competition between NG campuses and even between buildings and groups on the same campus. 

Not a good long term place for technically minded or younger/mid level engineers. High attrition with little loyalty/pride for current employees. The Dead Sea Effect (innovative folk evaporate, raising salinity, killing life) is in full effect. Lack of REAL technical expertise in key engineering areas leaves "leaders" who are glorified accountants or wannabe YouTube vloggers or well practiced sycophants. It's so bad in certain areas, they can't recognize/attract good hires because they don't have anyone truly versed in the state of the art to accurately gauge candidates' expertise. 

You will be treated as a number, especially every couple years when it's time to cut employee benefits and buy back more stocks/issue dividends. Even the laudable goals like "Diversity" are executed by management in a misguided, very prescriptive way that no one truly buys into, but games to increase their managers' numbers. The culture is not inclusive no matter how many metrics the CEO quotes in his video proclamations: it's an echo chamber.  As executed, even as a "person of color" I felt dirty by it. Managers with strong preexisting, but subconscious racial biases subtly advance "their own" to counteract the wave of "diversity hires" they think others are forced to bring in. 

The culture of "metrics gaming" is so strong, I wouldn't put it past people to submit fake Glassdoor reviews to help out their "Engagement Metrics".
advice_management:
Reorder your values. Employees were like #4 on the NGC list of values and it truly shows. 

People can see that the company is doing the absolute minimum it needs to for its employees no matter what you say. 

It will take a while, but you need leaders to make people to be proud of where they work, not accountants to manage their human resources.  Stop incentivizing management (at all levels) to screw over their employees.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for less than a year
pros:
I had the opportunity to work for the Northrop Grumman Technical Services as a designer and art director. Although I had over fifteen years of experience when hired, it was my first experience working for a corporation of that size. Needless to say I had high expectations. To this day I am baffled by the mixture of positives and negatives of my experience there. 

First, the positive. Almost everyone I worked with was very friendly from the first day. Professional, courteous, accommodating etc. I was hired part-time on-call yet they gave me 40 hours per week for the entire duration I was there. I was given the software I needed and one of the managers in particular was very helpful in that regard. Most importantly, they also had me working on a very compelling project, the details of which I am unable to discuss here, that enabled me to use my skills in a broad manner. For these things I was grateful.
cons:
This company apparently has terrible management. One manager (not my direct manager) directly asked me to work for free. He asked me to work on something on my own time since he did not have the budget for it. Being part-time on-call, I felt compelled to oblige him in the hopes that it would lead to permanent employment. 

My immediate manager appropriated a budget that I was awarded for a project I had conceptualized. This individual took every dime of that budget, such that I could not even pay myself to manage the project. The funding was granted by those in authority high above us, yet there was nothing I could do. I expressed my concern three times to this manager. He actually said, "I don't mean to cannibalize your budget, but ..." Yet that is exactly what he was doing. After assuring me that that funding would be based on my needs, he sent me an email, at home, mind you, with a list of everything he had procured, and it consumed the entire budget. 

The creative director, while always friendly to me, had two large dogs following her around wherever she went. Yes, just like the show The Office, but these were giant poodles. Being part-time on-call, I did not have my own office. I began in a large community cubicle space, and I was then moved into a two-person cube. Problems with noise led me to ask for permission to move into a vacant office nearby. I figured that, given my experience and the fact that I was leading a project, I should have my own office. There was just one problem, however. The office was actually used by the creative director's dogs. Unfortunately for me, I was less important than the poodles.

This is actually the point at which I left the company. Perhaps revealing my own naivety, I never imagined such things happening at a company like Northrop Grumman. I considered sticking around, in the hopes of advancing or opening other doors, but in our weekly meetings, on more than one occasion, management made it clear that there was no room for advancement at this particular location.

In summary, great people, poor management. I have no evidence that this reality is systemic. The feeling I got was that, in a hiring market, they can choose anyone they want to work there and they will have no problem finding individuals who will tolerate a reality such as I described. If you are ambitious and have self-respect then make sure you ask appropriate questions when interviewing.
advice_management: As hopefully evident by my experiences, management needs to see human resources as "people" and not as "resources" that are expendable.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Lots of opportunities for technical work (engineering, project management, software development, etc.) Got to work with space ground-control systems, communications systems, software development, satellite systems. I even got to see YF-23 Grey Ghost up close and some incredible technologies NG-EADS proposed for the tanker (our country's military loss for not implementing this). Received three performance bonuses which is unheard of in DOD contracts.
cons: Neopotism+Peter principal management+little chance to advance/transfer beyond position hired in to. Also, performance bonuses were so that the company didn't have to pay increased salaries. HR and "Engineering Center Managers" were NOT my friend. (Their mindset was more on laying off/hiring new staff vs. growing existing staff to keep contract fees down.) Loyalty was not rewarded. GREAT difficulty in transferring to another position/location upon end of contract. Diminishing benefits package that annually provided less and cost more.
advice_management: Employ a variety of feedback/recognition for top performance. The "one size" approach does NOT fit all staff, therefore listen to what your people are saying. Ensure non-attribution of skip level meetings. Give preference to existing and proven staff to other company opportunities and locations.
