cons: Many manager manage "up" meaning they couldn't care less about their organization; lots of egos - the "West Point-ers" especially act as if they know absolutely everything about everything; the work is usually more challenging due to schedule than due to complexity; In the defense industry, you'll find that your current assignment magically vanishes due to a change in government spending, but don't worry - you'll likely be doing the exact same thing on the next project, starting from scratch, until that assignment vanishes.
advice_management: More emphasis on Internal Research & Development (IRAD). While there is some, it seems to be more of a money handout to some teams rather than actual R&D that may lead to a commercial product to sell, or some new patent, or a new technology to demonstrate. It seems to be used as "filler" for teams while switching between projects.

summary: "Deficient "Leadership," Myopic Thinking, and Inflated Stock Prices"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
+ Decent Annual salary
+ Good Benefits 
+ Some really intelligent colleagues
+ Telecommuting options within some departments
+ Great amount of Paid Time Off
cons:
- No transparency in management to employee communication 
- Very little employee engagement. Management focus is primarily on "financial" numbers, their own hidden agendas, rather than putting the focus/attention on their "team" and helping to make them become successful.
- Too many short sighted "managers" and very little in the way of actual "Leaders"
- Very little experiential learning opportunities.  High promotion of SkillPort or other "online" webinars/videos advertised as "educational" tools.
- Reorganization every other year.
- Company values do NOT align with actual business practices.  Focused primarily on "customer" satisfaction and very little focus on employees (no engagement or development).
- HR has very little investment or direction in terms of L&D, OE, or succession planning.
- No Strategic Workforce planning.
- Supply Chain "leadership" is nonexistent (at least in the MS Sector). McLean and Annapolis Junction locations are delusional in regards to leadership, employee engagement, or employee development. This is a very TOXIC environment.
- Engagement Survey bandaids (short sighted thinking will never fix the problem)
advice_management: You've opted to layoff some of your most talented employees due to reorganizing the business to "better" align to the needs of your customers. Take a look at being more transparent in communicating with your employees. Stop rewarding micro-mangers, poor performing and unethical individual behaviors, and start embracing diversity of thoughts and focus on succession planning of "leaders" not managers.

For the most part, fellow employee's treated each other with respect and worked well together, of course there's always a handful of bad ones no matter where you work. Supervision was great when I first started working out there. {"OPS GRP"}
cons: As I moved on from "OPS GRP", there were a few good Supervisor's but not enough to stand out in the crowd of "Wrongly Positioned", "Unqualified", "Unethically Minded", "Ego Boasting", "Disrespectful" Supervision. The drive to get to work was a chore it's self {35 miles off the frwy straight out in the middle of nothing in the desert.}. Work overloads due to 50% of employed employee's not being qualified or knowledgeable about the position their in,  leaving the other 50% to do all the work load and Supervision finding that to be acceptable.
advice_management: Get out from behind your desks and locate your missing employee's and their hiding spots. Pay attention to what's really going on in the shop. Fill empty employee slots with only qualified employee's that can and will pull their own weight. Hold yourselves with an ethical and respectful mannerism with all and at all times. {Remember your title doesn't read, "GOD"}. Give merit where merit is due and not dependent upon being part of a click.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: One of the well-known organisations in the defence sector in the western world.  Each sector of the corporation operates with many projects that offer plentiful development opportunity for those that stay long enough and endure the hardship of living with minuscule pay in high-cost areas.  A lot of development resources are available to anyone with the equipments and time to access them.
cons:
Each sector of the corporation operates independently with seemingly zero synergy.  The legacy Information System sector was the cheapest sector of the corporation that offered woeful compensation package.  IS was the only sector that stopped pension and other retirement programme to supplement 401K.  Therefore any legacy IS employees in the current corporate structure will have to make do with working with colleagues that collect much more handsome salaries and retirement package.  Transfer between projects is a simple change of job locations and description because salary raise is never a possibility.
Work-life balance is non-existent for ground-level employees.  Managers cannot be bothered to say 'thank you' when one works through the night to deliver something to make deadline and overtime work is never paid.  Anyone foolish enough to demonstrate loyalty and dedication is rewarded with an universally given 3 for average for annual performance rating.  As with annual salary raises, anything above 2.5% should be considered a gift from God.  There is hope however because favouritism is rampant.  Anyone lucky enough to secure a senior manager's affection or has connection with high-level leadership can walk the easy paths paved with rose petals.
The company spends a lot of money on employee development but only if employee has a company computer to access the resources.  For everyone else that uses only project computers hopes and dreams is the only available option.
For anyone that hopes to join because Northrop Grumman was the maker of the F-14 Tomcat and the B-2 Spirit, look elsewhere.  Those glory days are long gone and never again.
advice_management: For a company likes to boast and gloat about its products of quality, it certainly has an interesting way of treating the people that build those products.  With the hundreds of billions spent on lobbying (wining and dining politicians and defence acquisition officials) but suffers persistent retension problems with young engineers I humbly suggest the following; you aren't the only show in town and the sooner you realise it and invest in your people the better it will be for everyone in your organisation.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros:

- Good salary
- Interesting work
- Great place to work if you are ambitious (Dont expect to be spoon fed work)
- My next 2 levels of management are great, pleasant and engaged
cons:
- Lots of nay-sayers who are jaded and are content on cruise control
- Poor review structure, "Everyone gets a 3" (scale of 1-5)
- Raises are a joke (2% - 3%)
- No bonuses, 401k match is just ok (3 year vesting)
- Benefits continue to be reduced (recent change to vacation structure reduces PTO accrual)
advice_management: Eliminate the bell curve rating system for reviews, it demoralizes employees that work hard and are recognized by their management but arent known at the director level.

summary: "Many diverse opportunities for ambitious engineers to develop core skills"

A lot of interdiscplinary interaction with room to be autonomous but opportunity to contribute to or lead a technical team once you have gained sufficient experience. Company is open to moving you around if you want to move in a different career direction.
cons: Can be easily stovepiped or pigeon holed to a specific role once you have demonstrated aptitude in that area; this can be detrimental if you are trying to develop breadth in your field. Bureaucratic processes can often get in the way of technical progress. Sometimes the working environment loses appeal to the youthful, energetic and empassioned crowd.
advice_management: Recognize mid-level engineers with opportunities for growth, training and learning. Allow and encourage comfort in original thought and challenging old methodologies of work.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Northrop Grumman Corporation works on very interesting projects. I had the opportunity to work on a team that gave me exposure to a multitude of different Software groups and platforms to develop on. The type of work you do here is difficult to find outside of the Defense Industry, and on top of that, Northrop Grumman is a leader in the industry for "smarter" vehicles such as UAVs.
cons:
1. Despite Northrop being the supposed leader in UAVs, it's software practices are terribly out of date. It's partially due to the industry and the length of the projects though. When a new project starts up, new tools are used and implemented, however those same tools will be used the entire way through, even if the project is more than a decade old. Trying to upgrade these tools or acquire new tools is a constant fight uphill with IT and layers of approval from upper management. 
2. Another con is not really a fault of NGC, but rather a reality of the industry. They are government contractors, and therefore bill the government a certain amount of man hours. This requires Software Engineers to always clock the hours. This is very out of the norm compared to the rest of the industry and takes a bit to get used to. 
3. There was a recent change to the rating program that rewards the top performers in the department with high score (5 or 4), normal performers with an average score (3), and poor performers with a poor score (2). This score is used to make the argument for raises and promotions for employees. On paper this sounds great, however a key detail is that only the top performers in the entire department are rewarded. This means even if you're a top performer in your own group, you can and probably will be passed for a higher score because only a percentage of 5's and 4's in the entire department. Managers convene to fight for the employees to get better scores, and use info written up by employees to help their argument. This is similar to the private sector, but I feel like it is handled a bit worse at NGC.
advice_management: Less management.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Good benefits.  Well managed retirement.  Autonomy for completing work.
cons: I had a good position with SRA Inc and was contacted by NG to come work for them.  Even though I really liked my position at SRA I decided to make the change because of a little more pay and primarily because it allowed telecommuting.  Not mentioning names, but the person who hired me did so very much out of self interest and did not explain to me the true nature of the contract I was joining.  After giving up my position with SRA and already working for NG I noticed many people were leaving for jobs with other companies.  It quickly became apparent my position was potentially very short with only a slight chance of joining the next contract. I would like to think this was as much a surprise to NG as it was to me, but I think that is naive thinking. It was pretty clear NG hired me to fill the gap until they completed their short term contract.  (In all I worked there about 7 months).  NG made some half hearted attempts to find me a new position on a new contract, but I was mostly a disposable piece to their financial puzzle.  Beware and ask lots of questions if you are joining a contract position with NG.  Dont assume they have your best interest in mind.
advice_management: Work harder to find employees work on new contracts.  Develop a slush fund and internal projects you can assign employees to until the next opportunity opens up.

summary: "Great Place To Work, But Don't Get Too Comfortable"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
- Very Stable
- Usually Predictable
- If you are smart and trusted, you can choose methods of solving problems
- Generally, no one bothers you as long as you get your work done. I show up around 9 or 9:30 and sometimes even later. I get my work done and everyone likes me. Cool :)
cons:
- Like any job, if you have a bad manager, life will suck. Moving around within the company is doable if you make friends and seek out job reqs. I had to quit my old manager and find a new one about 3 years into the company.
-- The company as a whole will not save you if your manager is a jerk. You just need to find a new one.
- Company is trying, but not keeping up with modern benefits such as free food, laundry, day care, etc.
-- They say they want to, but claim they'd rather funnel more money into internal R&D. Such is life.
- IT runs your life in the computer world. I feel like I am breaking rules when I try to run the latest version of Java, FireFox or Notepad++. This company is hyper, hyper paranoid about cyber security. I don't blame them, but I think there could be better options that don't impede actual Engineers doing technical, computer intensive work. 
- After being with the company about 6 years, my salary only went up about 25% total. I got fed up and entertained offers from other companies where I fairly easily got a 40% bump offer. Within a week my manager matched -- though I suspect my current salary is nominal. Great experience, but I do wish I didn't have to go through that song-and-dance and Northrop gave raises each year.
advice_management: Please keep up with modern employee benefits & bonuses! Cost cutting was understandable in 2009 during the recession, but now its time to give back.

summary: "Low Morale caused by poor management and lack of direction, training"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 3 years
pros: Good balance of experience across all levels, products, company ethics
cons: Management/leadership training is weak at this company at all levels compared to other company management/leadership training. HR and some program/product team managers have the attitude with new/newer employees of it's the Northrop way or the highway. These managers often do not provide direction or training assistance, rewards, interactions, or good performance ratings with the exception of favored long term employees, which has caused a lot of anxiety, low morale and commitment issues with employees of <5 yrs. Newer employees are scared away and if not already gone, may be planning to.
advice_management: Let lower level employees rate their managers during each mid-and final PMP reviews!!! Study what other comparable businesses do for their management / leadership training programs (e.g., AMA) and adopt improvements to the current program.

summary: "Solid company, flexibility helps with sometimes difficult customer schedule"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Working in proposal preparation can be trying, but when if it isn't extremely busy or things come up in your personal life, there is usually good work-life balance.  Managers at least make an effort to add to your experience within the department or sometimes in adjacent functions (rotational opportunities), and generally seem to care.  Northrop's benefits are good in the post-pension age (401k match, good PTO, health etc.).  Even when taking into account sometimes draining aspects of the job, it's a position most people would be happy to have.  Job stability should be good in government contracting environment, especially with Northrop.
cons: Working in proposal preparation can be trying... sometimes subject to tough customer needs/schedules, but more so the proposal development schedule (being at the end of the process, can end up working last-minute on things).  Managers can't/don't take much of a stand to alleviate this for their employees, but it's at least half due to the nature of the work that this is the case.  Need to make one's own effort for work-life balance at times to prevent burnout.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
-Off Fridays. 
-401K with matching
-15K a year for education
-If you just want to get in and get out, coast and have no desire to move up, this is the perfect place to work.
cons:
I could write a book on this...

-Getting a promotion is extremely hard and when you get the promotion the compensation is around 5%. Other aerospace companies give around 10% and additionally quarterly/mid year bonuses.
-Annual merits barely keep up with inflation.
-Facilities are disgusting. Some buildings are roach infested. Desks are from the 1930s. Chairs are uncomfortable and some are so old that they've retained the farts of engineers for the last few decades. Bathrooms are old as well and some have no ventilation so sometimes you get a nice surprise waft when you open the bathroom doors. It's honestly not the janitor's fault. The company just chooses not to provide money to repair the restrooms. Oh and sand paper is used in place of toilet paper.
-NGC has a contract with the food service, Aramark. The quality of food is equivalent to that which is served at senior centers. Mushy and tasteless. And of course the food is over priced. When there are meetings that do not provide charge numbers, the host/manager usually tends to "provide food" as to entice employees to come on their own time. Thanks, but I'm not going to wait until 1pm to eat Aramark mashed chicken even with a charge number.
-There is a lot of bureaucracy making it difficult to get work done. To get something like a Java profiler requires you to submit a request to IT and the job could be done anywhere from 3 weeks to 3 months, when it really should only take a couple of minutes. That's the "Value of Performance". Ordering and purchasing parts or software is a similar case, there is so much approval process you must go through that it hinders you from doing your job. At the end, your software which cost $500 ends up costing much more. 
-Health benefits are not full coverage like some other companies. Each year it gets more expensive and the coverage is less, but I'm not sure the company really has much control over this with Obamacare in play. 
-There is no free coffee and no free snacks.
-Wastes my weekend time writing reviews.
advice_management: They have all the advice they need from the Gallup surveys for the past 4 years.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I've been working here for 13 years.  I have enjoyed almost every minute of it.  I have had many opportunities to work different programs and positions, which ended up making me more valuable and well-rounded.  The work-life balance is fantastic.  I feel as if my management really understands that family comes first and allows me to make my family a priority as long as the work gets done.
cons: Sometimes I feel as if those that work hard and deserve recognition don't get noticed (I am not speaking for myself). Additionally, those that do not do their job well often get rewarded with promotions and/or more responsibility (I think this is more true with middle management).  I cannot stand the yearly-review process.  It seems so subjective and one bad comment on your review seems to hurt you for years to come.  By the time you receive your review, it's too late to change anything for that year.  However, if an employee was performing so poorly, it would be addressed immediately.  Obviously, none of these things is bad enough to make me leave.
advice_management: I would encourage/recommend to management that they listen to their employees.  We are smart folks with a variety of backgrounds and have great ideas for making the company better but also for potential work.  I also think that NG should get a better handle on communicating feedback to their employees regarding their performance more frequently so they are aware of their "status" and what they can do to improve or achieve a particular goal.  We too often wait until the day before the review deadline to communicate how we think we've performed over the course of the year.  I'm not quite sure how to solve this issue, but just know something needs to change.  I'm happy with NG and I appreciate all the opportunities I have had and hopefully will continue to have as I grow in my career.  Thank you.

summary: "Some good managers in the company but cutthroat environment when layoffs occur"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman

cons: When I was first hired, it was a little chaotic and I received very little training.  There seemed to be no strong corporate identity since so many people change jobs within the government contracting industry.  As the defense budget was cut, there was definitely an "every man for himself" mentality as people were trying to find secure jobs.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Amazing and challenging aircraft development programs at Aerospace Systems which are state of the art for the Defense Department. If you like developing new and advanced military and/or unmanned aircraft this is a great company to work at. 9/80 work week is wonderful in that it gives you a 3 day weekend every other week. Recently Northrop has reinvigorated its research and development efforts to help the company regain its technical edge which has resulted in some strategic wins. Excellent 401k program
cons: Company has changed its management approach to focus almost entirely on the shareholder, with the customer coming second and the employee coming in last. Lots of focus on “Engagement” which puts significant burden on line managers to improve morale but then VPs cut employee’s benefits which makes this impossible. Significant benefit reductions during the last 5 years with removal of the traditional pension, huge increases in health benefit costs, stagnant raises, and bonus plans that are based on VP’s favorites not accomplishments. Recent employee evaluation system has alienated 70% of the workers that are now identified as average and good raises and bonuses only going to the top 30%. This seems reasonable but the evaluation system is subjective not objective and gives the appearance if not the reality of only rewarding senior management’s favorite employees.
advice_management: Stop cutting benefits if you really want an engaged and talented workforce. Don’t waste time on non-value added benefits and provide quality health care for a reasonable price. Don’t cancel benefits that you have promised employees for years (pension, health) – demonstrates to all employees that the company can’t be trusted to stick to its employee agreements. Hire the best, talented, and qualified managers for senior positions not just who you know and like. Be careful with hiring people that meet your diversity quotas as this is another code for discrimination – if you hire the best, talented, and qualified people you will get a diversified set of employees.

summary: "Good Company, needs refinement of business model and corporate policies"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Fortune 500 Company and global leader in defense and government contracting. Good history of performance and highly talented and diversified workforce. Accommodates flexible work schedules.
cons: Despite application of agile software development principles into development workflow process the company business model is too rigid and not agile enough to keep pace with business development in today's economy. Constant reorganization places high level of pressure and anxiety upon employees making it an uncomfortable place to work. I understand it is a large corporation but it could do more to instill sense of job security; this would probably make environment more conducive for working. Lastly, the current business model makes it difficult to collaborate across business units (Operating Units, Divisions, Sectors, etc.), it's like employees have to pay other employees to collaborate with them, highly counter-productive.
advice_management: Allow the talented employee base more freedom to interact and collaborate without needing a charge number to do so. Minimize some of the bureaucracy and let your talented scientific and technical people lead a bit more. Stop inserting so much middle management into the process

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

advice_management: The Hollywood site may not be a major site in size, but it is located next to a major DoD activity and is very visible to this major USN customer.  Visibility to key corporate leaders is rarely possible and advancement overall is stunted.  Be more aware of the talent that exists in the field offices.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years

It's wrong and allows management to play favortism. So if a manager has 5 people in the group only 1 or 2 can get 5's and manager must choose to down grade the others because they have met their limit. People should be given what they earn and not be down graded because a manager can only give 1 or 2 people 5s.  It's a poor review process and in my opinion very unethical.  If 5 people are in the group and they all deserve 5s then they should get it.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Challenging projects with exciting emerging technology in Aerospace to work on. Fairly competitive salaries and a 9/80 work week to give you those much needed 3 day weekends.
cons: Management seems clueless about why the projects are constantly behind schedule and over budget. The suggestions of the engineers working on the projects are sometimes met with a "shoot the messenger" response. Hard to promote unless you know somebody up high in the food chain. Raises are small and you have to be Superman on Steroids to get rated anything higher then "3" or average on you performance review.
advice_management: The people who work for management know most of the reasons why things aren't working technically and what technical issues are behind the slips in schedule. Consider listening to employee warnings about problems during meetings and acting upon them. The work environment is unnecessarily stressful due to a Management culture that is quick to find people to blame for problems they've created themselves.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: If you want to roll into work and sit in a chair doing nothing for 40 hours a week, this is the company for you.
cons:
A giant old boys club. Are you a minority or a female? Look elsewhere. All the management and leadership in this building are white males. If they fail or perform poorly at their job, nothing happens. They just change their title and put somebody else in their spot. Layoffs and other big events never, ever touch senior management.

Huge amounts of waste and graft. Projects that could be done in 3 months take a year. Whats your incentive to be efficient and smart when you're working on a government contract? 

The vast majority of people who work at this company would struggle to be successful in any other setting. These are the B and C students of your engineering classes.

Constantly cutting benefits and weaseling their way out of things they committed to their employees. My favorite are the company-mandated shutdown days at the end of the year which are essentially a built-in furlough. 

Pay is absolutely horrendously bad. I went to work for a small company after Northrop and my first offer was 30% higher. That was before negotiation. I'm not anything amazing either, that just happens to be how far below market average this place pays people in general.

Working conditions are abysmal at best. Seriously the cubicles in this place are so old and stained and disgusting its unbelievable. Most of the furniture was installed long before I was even born. There are literally no windows and for whatever reason nobody in senior management sees this as an issue. All the facilities in Baltimore have windows, why doesn't this facility have them? Another great example of how little this place values their employees and their well-being.

Seriously, this has got to be one of the worst big companies to work for in America. You are doing yourself a huge disservice even considering working at Northrop Grumman. You may be reading this thinking "What a complainer, I have an offer I think I'm happy with." Trust me, I was there too, and years later I can't believe the mistake I made. Please, think really hard before going to work for this company. Unless you really want to just take it easy every day and you don't care about fair pay, good vacation time, or contributing to meaningful projects, this is absolutely a job you are going to grow to hate. Save yourself, just say no.
advice_management: Pay people better. When senior management sucks or fails, actually fire them instead of just shuffling the old boys club's titles around. Increase vacation time.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Slightly higher starting salary, stable work hours / shift for entry-level employees, 401k, medical / dental / life insurance, tuition assistance / reimbursement up to $15,000 annually; some really good people & managers with whom to work in certain parts of the company; nepotism-----current employees know other employees very well & are likely related to others throughout the firm (parents, siblings, cousins, childhood friends, long-time coworkers, etc.)----good if you know and / or are related to someone in the firm.
cons: sink-or-swim culture; company clearly reflects the decline of the aerospace defense industry via consistent budget cuts, understaffed teams, increased stress, lack and inadequacy of office & ergonomic equipment, inadequate / untimely training or investment thereof; nepotism-----current employees know other employees very well & are likely related to others throughout the firm (parents, siblings, cousins, childhood friends, long-time coworkers, etc.)----bad if you're averse to gossip & politics, especially that involving you; many unprofessional & downright bad employees & managers throughout the firm.
advice_management: invest more / better time & funds to provide better, comprehensive, structured, detailed, timely, recurring, up-to-date, work-related, necessary training to employees, beyond the simple & frequently lacking PowerPoint slide presentations; stop overly emphasizing / forcing engagement & team socialization----too much interferes with individual productivity and generally becomes a dread to employees who must sacrifice their PTO to "be part of the team;"  treat your employees well----clearly communicate and / or demonstrate gratitude toward your valued employees, provide positive feedback when just & earned, coach & help them when they fail, punish and / or terminate when just & necessary, maintain respect & dignity toward them, a small gesture goes a long way; restrain your anger & stifle your outbursts----if you have the time & energy to yell at your employees, then either you're making bad use of your personal & managerial resources or you're dealing with a truly bad employee (consult an unbiased & neutral party to decide).

summary: "Company Culture Update Needed to Ensure a Bright Future"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Work-life balance is generally good with most working a 9/80 schedule (every other Friday off).  Many opportunities to move laterally if you want experience in multiple business roles.  Opportunities exist for challenging/complex projects and roles.  Matrix environment presents excellent opportunity for cross-functional learning.
cons: Promotions are very difficult to achieve, both in-place and to management. Workplace diversity is painfully low.  Younger employees are difficult to retain because the company culture hasn't kept up with the times.  Merit increases have been very low for several years (0%-3%, generally).  Reorganizations and executive management changes are almost constant and executives just get recycled to different/newly created management roles.
advice_management: Please do a better job of engaging with and listening to your workforce.  Stop the overload of corporate jargon/mantras.  Do more to engage and train the younger generation to ensure a smoother transition with the upcoming "retirement cliff."

summary: "There's a reason you won't see Northrop on the lists of "best places to work""
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

cons: Northrop has shifted its priorities to shareholders and customers above its own people. This may be the "right" decision to make for the company, but it doesn't make it a good place to work.
advice_management: It's all about the people! Northrop used to recognize that its employees are its greatest asset -- the  unique knowledge and skill sets of its employees bring great value to the company. Cutting benefits, freezing promotions and pay should not be the first place the company looks to save money when it is pulling in record profits. The long-term strategy of reinvesting in the company's future through R&D is a great goal, but when it is at the expense of employee compensation and benefits you will lose top talent.

summary: "Better than I expected- I would work there again"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros:
There are a lot of resources available to Northrop employees, but you have to know where to find them.  My personal experience with the company overall was great, but the group I worked with had some management issues that the higher-ups seemed reluctant to address.
The thing I was the most surprised by was the dedication and commitment to quality that I saw on each of the programs I worked. I had come into the company expecting to find the lazy incompetence that you hear about in stories about stereotypical government contractors, but I really only saw a few isolated incidents of that attitude.
cons:
It all depends on the program you work on. I heard a few horror stories from people but didn't see blatant disregard for employees myself. 
The crunch of more work, less time/resources/support is inescapable, and I saw a few hard-working employees burn out.
advice_management: Everyone below a certain level is scrambling to make deadlines, so most of the management I dealt with was trying just as hard as I was to make it work. There were a lot of great opportunities that were missed because management wasn't able to follow up on BD leads.

I've worked really hard and in the last 2 years received 1 raise and because I started at a lower wage than what I should be making it was a small raise.. How am I suppose to support a family in la on these low wages and even at that when I work really hard not be able to achieve a good raise

summary: "Live by the contract, die by the contract"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Excellent pay; highly skilled individuals intent on accomplishing the mission. Great benefits.
cons: When the contract is over, so are you. Often the contracts are with government agencies that have not the slightest clue how to accomplish what's in the contract, but they're very quick to tell you what NOT to do. Very frustrating at times. Not a whole lot of time to actually dig into the inherent problems because the contract usually expects results NOW.
advice_management: Listen to the people you hire who used to work at the agency; they'll often know what's truly holding things up even though the agency probably doesn't want to hear it. Too. Bad. That's why they hired YOU.

Without trust in management or being able to see a future for yourself here (due to low pay, sad raises that only break even with the passed down increase in insurance cost), it's difficult to force yourself to care.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years

cons: The corporate culture there left a lot to be desired. Too frequently it felt like 120,000 employees all working in their own world. Collaboration was kept at a minimum and there was never the sense that we were all working towards a common goal.
advice_management: Be more cognizant of the need to get all employees believing in a beneficial end goal for the work that they were conducting. When it doesn't feel like the work is serving a purpose, which it often doesn't when projects are several years long, the work can seem menial.

advice_management: Learn how to do your job instead of just dumping on the people you are supposed to be managing. Give better raises.

summary: "Location of Work Campus drives your Career"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 5 years
pros: The salary for the work is competitive with other companies in this industry.  The benefits are standard large company offerings (health, dental, vision, life ins., disability ins.,  401K) as well as some added options for legal plan, EAP counseling, elder care planning, adoption, and numerous discounts for local area offerings - (i.e. cell provider discounted plan, car insurance, moving co. etc).
cons:
Costs and options with the health  plan of course changes every year to something that most believe it rounds out to more money for less service or fewer options.
Certain areas of the company - whether by division or just geo-location - end up being short sighted in business expansion and old fashioned in their approach to employees (continual berating or demeaning people in the guise of "motivation').
Some locations are not conducive to career growth due to stagnant "lifers" in the organization that are allowed to stay employed while they do nothing to advance the work of the business and live in the "glory days" . These management in perpetuity  are still pushing old tactics and refusing to empower the employees to steer the ship in a new or advancing direction for growth/continuity. 
The leadership is old and out of date and resting on their laurels
Business is being lost to more agile companies while focus is still firmly on what use to work and why it still works,.
advice_management:
Consider a complete refresh of management in areas that continually underperform in leadership qualities .
Stop putting out engagement surveys when you refuse to read what is being put down in these surveys for what is wrong with things.
Empower people that come forth with newer ideas to explore that for maximizing the business growth.
What got you here won't get you to where you want to go - stop relying on miraculous upticks in profit when nothing new is coming in and old business falls off because it was not managed to create efficiencies and competitive rates.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for less than a year

cons: Minimal communication between interns and large amount of engineering staff. I felt as though there were a handful of the engineers chosen to teach/instruct the interns and many others just steered clear.

summary: "This is a terrible place to work."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Decent pay, flexible hours, that's it.
cons: Everything else.  Not good benefits.  No recognition of talent.  Everything is a firedrill and therefore gets done half right.  The Rolling Meadows location feels like you're working in a dungeon.  The building has no windows and sucks the life out of you.  The company only spends contract money, and refuses to spend overhead, meaning that you end up having to "donate" your own time to work a lot - this is the worst policy the company has.
advice_management: Nix the current performance review system that scores everyone, stop treating employees like expendable assets or "heads."

cons:

- More talkers than doers...
- Ultra Conservative 
- Difficult to grow... even if you are recognized top-performer in the company.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: Employment is stable in the business areas. Once you're in, it's possible to spend your entire career there. The work is generally interesting and rarely slow.
cons: Compensation is below industry standard. There are no raises to speak of (2% is a good year) and  because there is not a lot of upward mobility, your salary never changes much. There is little incentive to work hard and many do just well enough to remain employed. It is also very much an old boys club. Diversity is encouraged at the executive level, but almost never put in place at the functional level.
advice_management: Remind yourself that you employ humans, not machines. Your employees are more than just numbers. If you want people to work hard for you, compensate them fairly and create an environment that welcomes everyone.

I have had a great manager that has been excellent with me. Ask for stretch assignments and there is a chance you will get that opportunity down the line. 9/80 schedule is awesome.
cons: Get rid of all the dead weight. A good chunk of employees are on cruise control and management is always slow to get rid of the lazy people. They hate laying off employees unless its on a mass layoff basis. Any other company would immediately get rid of  these people immediately if there is no work or they are not performing. In all departments i have seen its only 1 or 2 employees holding the whole department together. Lets get the 4/10 schedule going!
advice_management: Give more young engineers stretch assignments, it made me stick around unfortunately others left the company because they did not get that opportunity.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 10 years
pros: Northrop is a good company to work for.  I love the 9/80 schedule.  It helps you use less paid vacation time when you plan time off from work.  It is also a great company to for long term career growth.  There are a lot of different types of positions available, so the company have options to vary your career.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy at this company.  It is often hard to make changes to company policy and procedure.  There are a lot of employees who are "traditionalist", so it's hard for them to think outside the box in order to do something a different way.

summary: "Trying to rebuild, but struggling to adapt"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: If you're an engineer of some sort, your work can be really interesting and important.  If you're not an engineer, it's much harder to find positions that offer any kind of new/exciting work.  As most people have said, it's a decent place to build experience if you have no better options; just don't expect to really build anything lasting.
cons: A select few executives are really making an effort to bring NG into the 21st century, but they are being constantly battled by an entrenched core of management who do everything they can to stymie any progress.  These mediocre managers are good at playing the bureaucracy and political games, so they don't want to see meritocracy take hold.  The company claims to want the best and brightest (to compete with the likes of Google and Apple), but they aren't willing to invest the resources to compete (salaries, bonuses, perks, etc).  It's tough on morale because you hear all these awesome goals for the company, but then you watch each initiative slowly starve from lack of funding, lack of progress and lack of follow-through.
advice_management: Look around!!!  You have all these lofty goals, but as soon as the speech is over everyone in management starts downplaying expectations because there is no funding behind them.  You're going out on a hiring binge, but the employees you already have are pissed off because their raises have been miniscule for the last 5-7 years and you took away the annual bonus for 90% of them.  You keep talking about how everything is going to get better once we win some big contracts, but for most of the employees it's just empty promises.  While employees have borne the brunt of the hardship (lost raises, no bonuses, increased benefit costs, etc), the company as a whole has been churning out record profits!!!!!  Do you think no one notices?

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman  for more than 5 years
pros: Flexible work hours (9/80), Business Casual work environment, 401K matching.  The people you will work with are helpful and support each other; first level managers at least give you the time of day now, they're just as hand-tied as you are.
cons: Bonuses were taken away, lost another paid holiday (down to 10/yr), benefits have slipped significantly, work environment is not conducive to getting quality work done.  Upper management is satisfied with mediocrity and does not single out those who go out of their way to overcome obstacles and turn out great work.  You can expect to remain at your current level for 5-10 years without any prospect of moving up.
advice_management: Start paying attention to employees and attempting to show them some semblance of a future for their career, or be prepared to watch the majority of them walk out with much better offers.

advice_management: Keep your best employees and fire managers who lose contracts, not vice versa.

summary: "I enjoy working there.  The pay is a lot lower then I had expected as a structure 2 mechanic"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Longevity.  If you can handle getting paid less you can eventually get better compensation.  401k, and a partial match is ok.  Medical benefits are ok, not as good as you would think.  They do offer ed assist which is nice, if you choose to go to school while working at Northrop Grumman they will pay your full tuition as long as you pass the courses.
cons: The pay for a structure mechanic is a lot lower then expected.  Pay increases are low.  Structure mechanics don't get the support they need to be efficient.  They don't standardize the hours given to do a job from 1 build to the next.  On the books mechanics look like they are less efficient from build to build.  This is not the case, they are simply given less time to do the job.  This reflects poorly on the mechanics reviews which is a major factor in pay increases.
advice_management: Although upper  management preaches to their other managers support mechanics, we have a hard time getting the support we need.  I'd also would like to point out that entry level mechanics should have better pay increases.  At 3 years of service they should be a structure 2 mechanic and should be paid at least $20 per hour.  I'm training mechanics that are structure 4's they are making $25 per hour and I'm only at $17 per hour.  With 3 years experiance I can make at least $20 per hour if I were going to apply somewhere else for a structure mechanic 2 job.

summary: "Used to be better place to work"

advice_management: Don't think you know who are the valuable employees.  Treat everyone equally.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Excellent salary.   Meaningful work.   High ethics.
cons: Harsh work environment with tiny cubicles, endless noise, cold rooms, limited light, endless firedrills.    Many lost weekends, holidays, vacations, and evenings due to 24/7 culture that has no work-life boundaries.
advice_management: Reduce layers of management and focus on achieving priorities on time.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: They try to be professional. Key word: "try".  Understanding of family situations, etc. Decent salary for the area. But not for your expertise.
cons: Terrible management. Only professional, maybe 60% of the time. Play favorites on everything from scheduling, to telling different people about new benefits. Extremely stressful, and management/leads do nothing to help with it. Employees get lied to, but if you see an employee take it up with management, they're gone within weeks. The worst is the show they put on when CEOs come in to visit. Its borderline hilarious the difference in how they act. And they WILL NOT give good references if you leave for better opportunity, so do not let future employers call them. This was the case with 8+ people i know that worked and left there. They made it as hard as possible to leave, because they cant find skilled people to fill their positions (contracted positions especially)
advice_management: Realize the importance of a team. Dont just talk about it, be about it. Dont think your employees wont see you play favorites, etc.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Smart people, some leading edge technology if you're into aerospace/unmanned technology, 9/80 is nice when you can take advantage of it.
cons: SW development stuck in the 70's, old school mentality due to leadership being ex-military.  They just want people to salute and march to their orders.  There's no such thing as an enlightened discussion about other available options.  Pay and benefits for the basic worker does not match the typical tech company.  HR seems to think that salaries and benefits from the NW or MW are the benchmark for SoCal.  Continuos organizational changes.  As soon as a reorg occurs some new VP comes in and changes everything.  After a few of these you're not sure who's running what.
advice_management: You need to get fresh blood into the leadership.  Stop bringing in all these ex AF pilots who then bring in their former squadron mates into leadership.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year

cons: Gaurentted no pay raises, tools are cheap and limited. You have to be on a special list to move into management. Your co-workers will steal your stuff and lie to your face, (not to leave out throw you under the bus just for a little recognition) the managers stick up for their friends and cover up violations but are quick to get rid of people.
advice_management: Stay away from this place if your looking to advance, it may be good experience but the managers here will only tell you what they want you to know, unless you know the right question to ask, you may actually get some useful information.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman

summary: "Great company but an increasinly negative place to work"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great company legacy, exciting aircraft and space programs.  Good salary and benefits.   Good work/life balance for the most part, every other Friday off.
cons: The culture has changed dramatically over the last five years; management is more cutthroat and pays lip service toward goals such as employee engagement and diversity.  Has become a very political environment, sadly, with people undercutting each other to advance rather than helping each other to advance their careers.  Total loss of the reward of feeling like you're part of a team. I couldn't stand the ugly environment anymore after 14 years. (referring specifically to Space Park).  Opportunities for career advancement are based purely on politics versus the applicant's abilities.
advice_management: Stop with the constant organization changes already!  Get control of the politically-charged decision making and promotions, many people are getting hurt by it and that is why such a mass of smart people have left in the last two years.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: People are nice, I guess... If you want a really really easy job and have no ambition then this is great...
cons:
Innovation seems to be unwanted. Much of the time, one is handed 'legacy' code and expected to 'make it work'. No QA whatsoever, almost no standards, very much so an ad hoc culture.

It seems as though they have taken processes that may work for other industries and just applied it as a  'blanket' to everything. 

Benefits and pay are subpar for national average. 5/7 to be exact... 

Would not recommend. If you are a Software Engineer this is not for you, they will not let 'engineer' solutions, instead you will be asked to fix the borders on a table and be given code that does not compile. If you are a programmer and just want to program then maybe, but beware.
advice_management: You have technical people, you have business people, yet consistently you have only business people handling technical matters. Please stop. Look to other companies and their software process (preferably newer and more successful ones...) and compare it against yours. Let the embarrassment ensue.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
9/80 Flex Schedule/ 
Offer Health, Dental, Vision, 401k, 
Vacation (DTO/PTO)
LX Training Courses (Had to train myself)
cons:
Locally-"Good ol boy system"- no room for advancement unless you are one of them "good ol boy". Upper management does not practice what they preach, unethical practices take place everyday. 
If you report unethical behavior, cross charging, or misconduct get ready to be fired, demoted, moved, or "laid off" and bullied while the offender to get promoted. Can become a very hostile work environment if you do not comply with their demands. They will retaliate.
Corp NG however is like night and day, they take allegations serious and do not mess around. So far they have been very professional, but its sad that they cannot see how their reputation is being destroyed locally.
advice_management: My advice is to Corp Upper management: I know that your corporation is a big company and I have worked in the DoD contractor field for 10 years now, Before I was hired it was my goal to work with this company because the reputation was NG was the best... but on day one I walked into a huge shock... harassed day one, bullied, etc.. Please stand up for your employee's and do not promote repeat offenders to management positions so they can continue their abuse... Give people raises based on not only their seniority but also on their performance and merit and for going above and beyond. Also would be nice if the PM's weren't the only one's receiving bonus' after all its a team effort bring in business and build what is required... The PM's don't do it on their own so why should they be the only one's who get the big bonus. If the whole team works hard to make it happen the whole team should be rewarded.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

summary: "Tide of change has taken it's toll"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good benefits, good co-workers, world-class product line
cons: Political and social change has taken it's toll on the company. Tighter budgets have removed employee recognition, most qualified employees leave quickly. Do more (work) with less (help) is the unspoken rally cry.
advice_management: Mid-Level Managers - jump in and lead the team by example. Upper-Level Management - specify the goals your employees should be striving to achieve. When to goal can be seen the path can be as well.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than 5 years

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: Good healthcare and benefits. Supervisors were knowledgeable and easy to approach. Interesting, cutting-edge work. Always something new going on at work.
cons: Irregular, long hours. Lots of nights, holidays, and weekends. The company is split into sectors which do not communicate or work well with each other. If you're in a good sector, you get great health care, benefits and pay. In another sector, all of these might be mediocre at best.
advice_management: Don't make the sectors compete with each other for resources. It creates unhealthy competition between sectors and employees will try to leave one sector for another one.

summary: "Protecting people who are not doing their jobs"

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Decent benefits though they degrade each year, long time security if they like your product line, some employee satisfaction....for certain divisions and teams. So pick wisely. Great place to just get started, gain experience and go to a company that will actually value you and your work. Some upper managers believe that interns and beginner level employees can do the same amount of work as a senior developer without the senior pay.
cons: Incompetent managers in some departments that do not care for anyone below their level and are too busy working on that promotion. You are just a number and sometimes that number seems to be based more on favoritism than actual achievement. Any company that limits the number of high remarks that can be given and not truly look at what people do...just goes nowhere. If you are seeking to be just a theory out of school manager that can set all these ideas and then not carry though, but get promoted instead....go for it. Experience and dedication has no value...see pros.
advice_management: Start listening and paying attention to the smaller groups that do a lot more work than the bureaucracy....i guess that is the nature of a big company but those senior employees that have been there for decades are more than experience but actually have dedication and commitment to work. When your engagement studies keep getting lower, start looking at the management that is ultimately responsible. Don't ask employees what is wrong and then ask them to fixed themselves.

cons: The employee review process is somewhat of a joke (if you're not one of the "important people" or in high visibility situations). Managers will give you no areas to improve upon, yet rate you low, give a low raise, and make you wait longer than necessary for a minor promotion. There is a high turnover rate because of this process.
advice_management: Start giving employees what they're actually worth.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Northrop Grumman provides its employees flexible hours, full payment of most graduate degrees, and if you get into it, the Professional Development Program (PDP), which allows rotation of jobs for new college graduates to find the right fit, is an awesome experince. They also offer generous relocation packages and offsite rotations through this PDP program.
cons: If you're not going to school or in the PDP program or relocating, it's just a very average place to work. The jobs feel unengaging, the benefits are constantly being slashed, the CEO is greedy, and the raises are a mediocre 3% a year if you do a "decent" job. I also feel like there aren't as many opportunities as there should be. They use outdated technology and are far too restrictive.
advice_management: You need to find a way to keep the PDPs once the program is over; they are the future of the company. There is literally no real reason to stick around otherwise once you have earned all the degrees you want. The benefits are constantly being slashed, and the CEO is extremely greedy.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: If you are lucky, you can work on a program that has a cool mission, since a lot of it is classified work. So it's fun stuff. Also, for a brief time, I worked with a really motivated and exciting team. Which means there are some cool people there. However, you are not guaranteed either since you get moved around from program to program depending on the needs.
cons: 1.) Heavy corporate politics, 2.) Uneducated government managers providing detrimental, inefficient oversight, 3.) Schedule, metrics, and bean counting all supersede the software engineers' input. 4.) A top heavy, un-motivated elderly population combined with an unrewarded, both by satisfaction, and by compensation (due to budget cuts), young talent results in daily cynicism from both groups of people.
advice_management: Stop hiring more "people" managers when the technical aspects are behind schedule. Also, you spoiled the baby boomers with pensions and great benefits, but now you are screwing your young talent with all your budget cuts.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman  for more than a year

advice_management: When a project fails due to no fault of the workers (it was clearly mismanaged from day one) don't make the lower paid workers pay to relocate just to stay with the company - throw them a bone in the form of some reimbursement for moving.

summary: "Great place for your career to die."

cons: Chances are that you will do boring, mundane grunt work most of the time.  There are a few opportunities to actually get your hands on new things and to actually write a new application but those are rare.  Mostly it's fixing bugs, porting those fixes to various base-lines, and doing grunt work like Fortify analysis and fixes.   But on the plus side, at least you won't be paid very well. .
advice_management: Those engagements surveys are a joke.  I can think of only one person that I worked with that actually took it seriously.

advice_management: An employee should only be responsible to report work status to their direct manager, not a multitude of managers all inquiring about the same information throughout the day. This impedes the employee from performing their function efficiently.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years

cons: Defense usually keep a lot of dead wood around. Meaning there are people who are not good at what they do and it's annoying to deal with them. Things are never cutting edge. Pay is about 40% lower than in commercial world in some of the more expensive areas of the country.
advice_management: Invest in your people and yo'll never go wrong. Investment == $$.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Great growth opportunities for those that seek it. I started as a Tier 3 engineer and worked my way up to program manager within 3 years. Fantastic people, and great mentors.
cons: Once proposal season hit, the work was nonstop.  Night work, weekend work, and working through a weekend were not unheard of. Reorgs happened every other month. In 4 years, I had 7 different bosses. Starting pay was low and the only way to get a decent raise was to get a counter offer.
advice_management: Slow down on the reorgs.  Move employees to different contracts to gain more experience.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Most positions are on a 9/80 schedule, which will give you every other Friday off in exchange for an extra hour Mon-Thurs. Everyone is allowed to express their opinions. Highly, highly ethical organization (may be a result of DCMA auditors always being around, but whatever the reason, if you have integrity, this is the place for you). You often get to work on things you only get to read about. Great work/life balance overall... occasionally a project may temporarily disrupt this, but even then, in at least some instances the company will provide straight overtime even though you are salaried.
cons: HR is the biggest issue here. They take the job requisitions very literally, and so you often have people who are only qualified on paper in a role they have no business being in, while talent has to sit around until they have enough years to qualify for a given role. Merit based bonuses for lower level staff are extremely difficult to get, although surprisingly high (for non-sales folks) if you do.
advice_management: Fix your HR, pronto. They know nothing about the programs, nor do they know the existing employees line managers have often worked with and spotted potential in, so they reject your real talent, which hurts the project when the wrong person is in the job and may eventually drive away the talent because they don't want to wait 6 years to get promoted.

advice_management:
There is no way to move up in Northrop Grumman unless you are Retired Military, of a certain sex or your spouse is in upper management.

There is a reason that Northrop Grumman floods Glassdoor reviews with a positive message.

Don't get me wrong Northrop is a great company if you want a job, and want to coast for the rest of your career.  But if you are ambitious or seek to actually contribute, this is not the right company for you.

PTO time is very generous, and holiday shutdown is perfect.  These two benefits alone keep people at Northrop.  The salary increases are 2-2.5% annually.  It doesn't matter how hard you try, how many corporate awards or recognition you get, you are not going to get more than 2%.

Most of the younger engineers spend a few years at Northrop Grumman, and then jump ship to a higher paying position.  If raises were higher for all employees at Northrop productivity would increase and the high turn over costs could be reduced.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros:
-Stable paycheck.
-Decent benefits, stock options, healthcare etc.
-9/80 Schedule
cons:
Where to begin....
-I was hired fresh out of college as an industrial engineer. I was told the position would be more oriented towards lean manufacturing and support. Currently, I run reports and make charts that track how production is progressing rather than actually help production be more efficient. In short, we produce reports, management looks at reports and yells at lower levels to do better. It's abusive and a complete waste of talent. I'm an engineer being paid an ok salary to click buttons.

-Old and Slow. Business has been slow the past few years and Aerospace Systems continually has been cutting investment. I've never seen a company rely so much on people and machines and then unwillingly invest in them. We literally run machines  24/7 in order to meet schedule, neglect preventative maintenance and when they catastrophically fail, wonder what happened. The same is true of employees.

-No training, expectation of perfection. I received about an hours worth of training my first day from a co-worker who had been there 30 years and acted as if I was imposing on their time. People are busy, but lacking any formal training or investment in people is egregious. Worse, it's just sad when management fails to give you that training and expects your work to be perfect on the first go. Further, people don't help until their butt is on the line. Otherwise, you tend to be on your own.

-Huge age gap. Aerospace has been struggling lately and has held onto many tenured employees, while laying off less tenured ones. They then hire in new graduates to back fill a 30+ year employee. I have no problem against older employees, but when you're the only 20 something in a group...you know there's something wrong. To compound that, the company is bleeding younger folks. Most 20 somethings I've met in the company are looking for other jobs outside of Northrop.

-I feel bad for my managers. Management works about 60+ hours per week, constantly on their blackberry or responding to e-mails. They don't have time to mentor or even meet with employees on a regular basis. Adding to that fact, most of them don't know how to manage. On a regular basis I watch managers berate employees. They ask for turn around times on tasks that are rather impossible and then insult employees when they can't meet those expectations.

-Raises. I received a 2% raise my first year. This is barely in line with inflation and laughable at best. I've met many folks who've come out of retirement to assist Northrop from "the glory days" and they are some of the best and brightest people I've ever met. The company has retired them, cut salaries and recruited cheaper, but less adequate managers whom can't manage and are generally miserable people.

-Old facilities. My workplace has not been touch in 20+ years. The carpet is old and stained, computers are slow and the floors are peeling up. The companies attitude shows in its neglected and antiquated buildings.
advice_management: I hope you get another good contract so you can hire better people and have a massive cultural overhaul. Otherwise, you'll be Boeing in  a few short years.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: It's a job and pay's my bill.
cons: Where do I begin? Been with the company for almost 8 years. Depending where you work, it's like prison. You have to pick a clique to survive here as it's every man/women for themselves. Your co-workers that you thought were your friends at work will not waste anytime to throw you under the bus to make themselves look better. HR seems like they are always on the prowl to get people fired right away. If you don't work for the Aerospace Systems sector, they treat you like the red headed step children. Meanwhile the Aerospace Sector would get bonuses for saving the customer money and give everyone else cake. Don't get me wrong, I'm just lucky to get a paycheck but everyone should be treated equally if they want everyone to go by the motto "One Site, One Team!". No matter how hard you work and go out of your way for the company, they will not waste no time at all to point out each and every little mistake you've made. The pay is ok, but could be way better. When I first started with the company it had that family vibe, that is until all the good people left either by retirement or promotion and then  that's when the corporation vibe came in. It went from higher ups knowing you personally by name to now you're just a number. They stress on the importance of people taking these Ethnics training classes annual which is a waste because the company does not follow what they preach. Example, one of the quizzes they give they talk about a gentlemen who's daughter was going to college and wanted to join the company as an intern. Her father happened to know/work with the Manager for the intern spot. They give you multiple choice answers, A). You tell the father that his daughter must apply online like everyone else B). The father gives the Manager his daughters resume and the Manager brings her onboard. Which one is the right way to handle this? Obviously A) was the correct answer however, I have seen instances where apparently the company believes B) is the correct answer on what seems to be on a daily basis. This "Job" is just a place holder for me until I add a few more experiences on my resume and will leave. Defiantly not a company you want to put 100% effort in everything you do and not be recognized and then treated like crap.  Lastly, biggest pet peeve with the company; not once I have meet our newest VP's and Vice VP's. Before or best VP and Vice VP left for better things they used to walk around greeting everyone individually, asked how they were doing, and asked if they needed anything. Now we get these newer folks that have not even introduced themselves to anyone; I guess as long as they get there bonus checks every year based off of our hard work there is no need to meet them.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: In general, my coworkers are dedicated, and personable.  Free parking.
cons: Workloads are highly varied, and not recognized by management.  Bonuses were eliminated for all but management and the most senior employees in 2014.  Pay increase pools were in the 1-2% range for the last 4 years.  At the same time, open positions go unfilled because qualified people with a security clearance are a limited resource.  Morale is low as measured by corporate employee surveys, but there is no effort to correct the driving causes (low pay and excessive workload).  I've worked on average 400 hours of overtime for three years, which is incongruous with a token insulting pay raise.   Shareholder value is increasing geometrically, but with such low morale, expect that to be a short term spike.
advice_management: Reconsider your salary structure.  Underpaying highly skilled people with security clearances isn't sustainable.  We'll find better jobs.

pros: Decent salaries and benefits, smart people to work with, some flexibility.  nice work out facility and cafeteria.  Great people here that tend to stay for years.  It's definitely not the worst place you could work.  They made it worth my while to come and work here.

job_title: Current Employee - Software Development Analyst III
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Pay is decent.
While I hate the annual ethics training, it does show how important it is to the company.
My position allows for minimal direct supervision, just get the work done and make the client happy and nobody will be breathing down your neck.
Good vacation and personal time off amounts.
Good retirement contributions.
cons:
A lot of the positions offered by Northrop Grumman are contracts that could be lost on any given year.  In regards to that, the pay should be about 10% higher than competitive jobs that are less likely to go away.
Insurance deductibles might be industry standard, but if you want to be an exceptional company, bring them down considerably.
advice_management:
Occasionally, there are higher paying opportunities available for me that have no risk of losing a contract from a competitive bid.  Some assurance that other projects would be available to keep developers employed would help keep developers from switching to a competitor for peace of mind.  Consider a CDHP with a higher employer HSA contribution that bridges the gap in the deductible.  

Also, allow employees to use their FSA funds towards the plan deductible before drawing from the HSA account.  For instance, if I go to a Dr. for a visit, I can use my insurance card and it deducts the cost from the HSA balance and it counts towards my annual deductible.  However, I am not able to have the visit count towards my annual deductible but pay it from my FSA account.  I either have to let the funds come from the HSA to count towards the deductible, or I have to forgo the use of the insurance card and use the FSA account which will not get counted towards the annual insurance deductible.  I don't like this at all because FSA funds are lost at the end of the year, while HSA funds roll over.

If you're one of the ones chosen to travel you will be going to exotic places for extended periods of time.  If you're someone who enjoys doing nothing all day long and getting paid this is the place for you!  If you like to work in an environment where it's not clear who the boss is you will love it there.
cons: I could spend a week listing all the cons of working here because this is the most dysfunctional organization I have worked for in my life and that includes all of the jobs I had as a teen.  The biggest con of working here is that the upper management is unethical in more ways than one.  Management at this facility need "respect" training and need to be retrained in ethics.  To list a few other more trivial cons; as an engineer the experience you gain will be of no value when you leave because you're engineering nothing, just assembling and testing parts, business travel with extended time away from home, no chance for promotion, engineers with little to no experience are the real managers because the "managers" are so weak, people who are called, "engineers" but have no engineering degree.  Based on this it's not clear who the boss is.  One manager I dealt with clearly saw us a boy scout troop to be managed in the same way....."a leader shall emerge!".  That same manager would use examples from a sci fi TV show as to how the organization should be run.  Management is out of touch with what's going on day to day so there is no recognition for your achievements or failures.

summary: "Once great, now incompetent management and HR"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: At this point in time, work-life balance is the only good thing about this company.
cons: About 5 or more years ago, most employees were working hard and had a great outlook on their future.  NG used to be a great company run by intelligent engineers.  Today it seems like profit is the only thing that matters.  We keep seeing shareholders rejoice at their inflated stock prices, and hearing about how the Execs are making millions in salary, yet the engineers doing all the REAL WORK keep having our salary increases frozen or miniscule (1-2% raise) every year.  Meanwhile our benefits keep getting cut back as well.  So what does this tell the engineers (the backbone!!) of this company?  Seek work elsewhere.  When you work overtime for weeks/months on end to make a deadline, then receive only a "passing" grade in your performance review, and a microscopic raise, guess what happens next?  People either leave for better opportunities at other companies, or work very lazily in protest.  Middle and upper management are completely incompetent, as well as the HR department, because if you ask for a raise or promotion, they will promise you everything to keep you working for them, then conveniently "forget" when the deadline comes around.
advice_management: Quit for the good of the company.  And for the higher management, REPLACE the entire HR department and hire better middle management.
