main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Lots of challenging work at the system of systems company.  Lots of training opportunities for those willing to invest their spare time in classwork or company initiatives.  Decent budget for job-related classes.
cons: We are working in an austere environment.  Lower costs are more important than a technical improvement.  New processes evolve fast and require management intervention during "upgrades."
advice_management: keep a balance of low volume satellite business expertise vs aircraft high volume business.

summary: "Overly managed, spends more tracking budget than development of technology"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Diverse culture. Most workers are very passionate what they do despite the amount of rework due to change in program schedule.
cons: Overworked. Lack of extended work week hours. Lack of functional management concern on finding new homes for employees after a program has ended.
advice_management: Take the time to learn the concepts that are of concern by your team. Sometimes meeting schedule is not always the best thing for the program.

summary: "used to be great, question higher VP;s motives at this point"

summary: "A great employer while the money is there"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman part-time for more than a year
pros: Northrop Grumman is a great employer with generous benefits and very interesting work. The range of technical and engineering jobs spans a swath of disciplines that suit almost any recent grad interested in tec.
cons: As with all contracting companies, cutbacks and downturns come with risks. If a contact dries up, so does your job.
advice_management: Work for your company, but don't forget your employees.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Full company benefits and regular raises.  Groups are like separate companies almost.
cons: Quarterly review process is quite silly (setting goals for yourself but goals are whatever the contract is that you are working on).
advice_management: None

summary: "Industrial Workplace nestled in a nice locale."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Everyone wants to do a good job.  Cafeteria on premises and nearby restaurants provide a lot of good places to eat lunch.  Decent learning and development opportunities.
cons: Management is very secretive.  Very poor organizational communication.  A bit of a good old boys club.  Instead of promoting their best people they promote people who have been there the longest and who won't rock the boat.
advice_management: Let your leaders lead.  Don't be so overbearing and give your people the trust they deserve to do the right thing.  You espouse a lot of Six Sigma principles but fall short of actually implementing it business wide.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good hours.  980 (every other Friday off).  Virtually impossible to get fired for anything other than budget cuts.  Very low expectations.  Promotions are on a timer - you get promoted after X number of years, not after demonstrating your worth.  Very attractive if you don't want to work very hard.
cons:
Enjoy your 2% raises while the CEO rakes in upwards of $20 million every year.  No promotions/pay increases for the top performers.  Some bonuses are given out very discretely, but are not very large at all (typically less than a signing bonus from any other NG's competitors).  HR has an absolute death grip on the company.  First level management is generally terrible.  The company cannot stop re-organizing (I was part of 6 re-orgs in about 4 years).  The facilities are hazardous to your health - especially El Segundo and Manhattan Beach.  The stuff floating around in the water and air is literally toxic.  

Do not work here if you are young, motivated, and expecting big things for your career.  You will find yourself pigeon-holed, doing 3x as much work as the 25 year veteran sitting next to you, who is getting paid at least twice as much as you.
advice_management: Quit.

summary: "Company goes all out when they really want to hire you. Relocation package included. Generous travel reimbursement."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: This company has a lot of contracts with the DOD and are always looking to create new ones. It is a company whose upper management knows how to keep the work ($$$) coming. They plan well in advance to assure a successful future. The pay is pretty good and they provide training to assure your success on the job. A very well organized system. Best experience with a company so far.
cons: The only cons is that a lot of the work may be boring paperwork and following strict procedures, but that is the price to preserve our country's vital national  security interests secure. Very strict with breaks and to keep everyone very efficient they do not allow internet access except for travel maps. Obviously this restriction keeps many employees from being fired for improper use of the internet.
advice_management: Don't change all the things that work so well.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros:
We live, work, and play super close to the beach.

The salary let's you live reasonably well, just watch those non-discretionary bills like happy hours, cable/internet, and of course: eating out.

Northrop Grumman has been around for many years, and has acquired numerous companies throughout it's history: One day you're working with a new grad, the next you're with someone who built a Space Shuttle in Palmdale, or a military test pilot from New York!  

There is no shortage of uber-smart people around.
cons:
Huge age gap, which the entire Aerospace/defense industry is trying to address before it becomes dire.

There's still people printing documents, signing them, scanning them, and then sending it thru email - we build satellites for Pete's sake!

The cute girls are few and far between - you can check out the beach/soccer mom's in Manhattan Beach though!
advice_management:
Flow down more information, let us know more about the "big picture." 

Or just tell us about how you got to your position, what other chances could you have explored AND why did you not?

job_title: Former Employee - Subject Matter Expert Level V
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Comparing to most employers, NG has a very good benefit package, which includes two pension plans. Vacation days start from 17 and employees gain 1 additional day every two years.
cons: Big overhead, of course. This is a large company.
advice_management: Reduce overhead

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: company resources are vast, top notch employees
cons: poor leadership at division level
advice_management: leverage younger employees more effectively. age discrimination is rampant

summary: "Good company, great people, questionable business decisions"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
Decent salary.
9/80 work periods (80 hours in 9 days = every other Friday off)
Very smart co-workers.
cons:
Moving most Bethpage jobs out of state in the next year.
Business is very dependent on government budget issues.
Many antiquated, cumbersome security policies that need to be updated.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The work was decent and interesting. They also allow a 9/80 schedule which is a big plus! Pay is decent.
cons:
Seniority over attitude. Policy consistently result in the best and brightest leaving (e.g. requiring relocation across the country, only seriously considering the opinions of the grey beards)

Middle management, in my experience is extremely lacking in this technology company. This is across the spectrum from technological understanding to work practices. For instances it's commonly acceptable for management to make statements like "I really don't understand this, its for the smart people to understand" in regards to basic technology concepts like ethernet or Linux. Management also values working overtime and doing nothing higher then working 8 hours and accomplishing task. The more hours you sit at your desk, there is just an assumption that your actually doing more. There is also no vision or risk taking whatsoever and this costs the company overall in loss of contracts due to stagnation. Middle management also cannot identify key people and skill levels of the employees.

I will say though, that this is my experience at one location, other sectors and locations may or may not be different.
advice_management:
Take some chances, not just on technology but people. Consider promoting based on merit, enthusiasm and ideas rather then just years in service.

Also work harder to retain good people. I've seen some great people leave due to lack of opportunity. Some of these people cannot be replaced and can be extremely productive.

Constant cuts to benefits are a clear signal to employees to look elsewhere. Management should address this to retain good employees

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Worked with a lot of cool technology and got a lot of good hands on learning experience.  Benefits were really great.
cons: seems to have cycles of hiring and layoffs.  Promotions and pay increase process seem to be heavily weighted on who you are friends with.  I was told I had a great year but only so many people can be promoted so maybe next year...for a few years.
advice_management: reward and try to hold on to the good new hires

summary: "Great place to work, but no longer a secure job thanks to Sequestration!"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great place, management and employees
cons: Thanks to Sequestration, no position is secure

job_title: Current Employee - Software Development Analyst I
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros:
The managers I have had are very flexible. They allow everyone in software development to work from home 2 days a week and don't mind you working from home if you or a close family member is sick. 6 weeks until I went on maternity leave, my boss called me and told me that he would allow me to work from home until I delivery my baby. I live an hour away from the facility so that was very nice of him.

My workload is as I choose it to be. I can take on as many projects as I have time for. There are also a lot of  opportunities to gain lead experience or to move over to admin or database work. If you want to go back to school or take up  a certification, the company will pay $15K per year in my sector. I really like working for this company.
cons: They aren't upfront about pay so you don't know if you are being paid fairly or not. There are also secret bonuses that certain people get offered discretely. Lastly, promotions are kept quiet. There are some level 2s and 3s that will only list Software Development Analyst on emails and such. Because pay isn't published, you don't really know how to plan your career path.
advice_management: Keep up the good work but please let HR know we would like salary information so that we can better determine our career paths.

summary: "This is a large company and you feel it in the layers of bureacracy you face."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Ability to do flexible work schedules.
cons: Forcing employees to take vacation or LWOP when there is a break in a contract.  Even when the government money is coming they will not carry you a single day on risk.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Large company -- many opportunities exist to make lateral transitions and expand your career
cons: The company is large enough that it has to manage by the numbers -- it can't take care of individual employees like it did in the past.  Your career development is 100% on your shoulders and your continued employment is 100% on the company's shoulders.  In all fairness, I was layed off by this company and it was a total surprise to me at the time which clouds my review.
advice_management: I don't have any advice to management, it's a pretty good leadership team.  My advice is to employees: don't think you're indespensible (even if you are), and have 6 months salary saved up -- 3 months is not enough in the current environment

summary: "Supported the AEHF 4 and 5/6 Production Programs for the project control of a major component.  Responsible for the init"
job_title: Current Employee - Program Cost Schedule and Control Analyst IV
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: The company is reowned for developing quality products for the US military.  It is a solid company with great benefits and many growth opportunities.
cons: When the defense budget is cut, there is a "domino effect" on government contractors.  That is the downside of this business.
advice_management: I enjoy a management style that allows their employees to be creative, innovative, and that allows for team playing.

summary: "Amazing Company all depends on who you get for a supervisor!"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Amazing company to work for, intensely interesting work. You will be working with the top people in their field.
cons: Once in a lifetime you get your dream job but the worst supervisor, this was one on those times! This can be a GOB old school environment.
advice_management: Narcissistic personalities in employees that supervise others get in the way of productive work, these types of personalities should not be supervising or managing others, they are very difficult or impossible to control. It resulted in my quitting this position, first time in a long career to quit!

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Ability to move up quickly or across multiple programs because the company likes to use its resources to their full potential.
cons: The only cons that I have seen is the difficulty cutting through the bureaucracy that can short circuit a project as it is getting off the ground.

summary: "Underwhelmed - don't stay here long, just get some experience and leave"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Mostly hardworking coworkers focused on the deliverables we've committed to.  There's a strong sense of purpose to completing team goals.
cons: Terrible focus on employee growth except for interns and short skirts.  Northrop's annual salary pools are worse than their competitor's and don't inspire anyone to excel.  There benefits are becoming less competitive every year.    They really don't plan to keep anyone longer than a few years since they only pay new employees well to get them to join.
advice_management: You conduct an annual employee survey, and then ignore the negative answers.  If you  focus on improving your survey results through actual change, you'd be unstoppable. Alas, we all know the survey is just Fortune 500 window dressing.  I bet the executives get a giant bonus even when the results don't improve.

summary: "Opportunity to learn and grow while working with some of the best professional experience in the world"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great work models, pay, benefits, time off, regular opportunities to advance, opportunities to transfer to other work sites or cross-train into another field, full open-door policy all the way up to the top.
cons: Little supervision on some sites, union biases from supervisors at times, difficult work conditions (rain or shine the work gets done), and often the work is done outdoors regardless of the climate conditions (cold, hot, wind, sand, and humidity- doesn’t matter), pay generally compensates for difficulty, though the “military mentality” is the general culture where some may find this kind of environment difficult to work in.
advice_management: Opportunity to advance is available to everyone including company provided training/cross-training to other fields, college reimbursement, easy transfer to other locations or work sites through an open-bid process (state-side, around the world, or the shop next door). One-on-one professional counseling from Human Resources, management, and training specialists to aid in promotions.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: You are allowed freedom to work in a friendly atmosphere. At least I was while working on the F-14A, B and D flight test programs.
cons: I have no CON feelings from NGC. I enjoyed the 33 years I worked for the company
advice_management: Stay the course and keep our country strong and free with your innovative products. Make the last year of employment  and length of employment options a bit broader to encompass longer time for retired personnel more effective

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Good environment and some of the best people to work with
cons: Extremely Low wages for Engineers, they pay about 20% below the market value and only give 1-2% raises from year to year. I know an engineer who has been working here for 6 years and is still in the 50s in salary
advice_management: Pay market value to employes

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
You can get off for family affairs if and when you need to....
You get to work as many hours over 40 as you would like with no extra pay, no problem!! 
You get to use spreadsheets like toilet paper. You get real good at those.
cons: If I had another job I would not continue to keep this one as the economy is still not good as we all are aware. This company talks out of both sides of their mouth at best. They only promote the same small circle of people around in circles, make up new job names and move them around. If you don't have a brown nose you will go no where regardless of your skill or experience level. They break ever rule in the book when it comes to employment law. Salary or exempt they work you what ever way suits the purpose. I have not seen my manager in 6 weeks which is normal. He hardly ever calls you much less supports you if you have an issue. If you report a problem about the atmosphere or work habits then you are not a team player. The raises are less than 1% a year for the last several years no matter what your evals says even good evals get hardly anything. They think 60 hours a week is 40 for some reason. Am I just being bitter no this is the opinion of many of my co-workers except many never heard of glass door to post their opinions. They could really be a stellar organization if they would open their ears and eyes. They have a yearly gallop survey that reports the same bad news every year but does nothing to improve the situation. We then have big meetings saying how good we are doing and the stock is great but the money never sifts down to the worker bees. If you are young and impressed by the name come on aboard. if you want a real career that means something and a company that values your opinion then don't waste your time here. You will be disappointed but in Richmond VA they have the run of the town and the only other major player is capital one where they lay you off after 23 months and 29 days. Here we sit come on aboard if you wanna!!
advice_management: Stop wasting time with the stupid gallop poles and all those stupid engagement summits. They are pointless as everyone is scared to speak up because they fear being fired if they do.

summary: "Great company with people who car about what they do, but it can be improved."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros:
1.  Competitive pay and excellent benefits, including flexible work arrangements for many people (9/80, 4/10, WFH).
2.  Exposure to interesting cutting edge engineering technologies.
3.  People who care a lot about their mission to help protect warfighters.
4.  Lots of opportunities for advancement.
6.  Good work life balance.
cons:
1.  Lots of meetings that don't seem to have a purpose.
2.  Ineffective managers and staff are often coddled.  These individuals are not fired and often are not even confronted for their inappropriate behavior.
3.  Very hierarchical organization.  Although "open door" is promoted, using it is not likely to get you the outcome you desire.
4.  Some areas of the company are understaffed.
advice_management:
1.  Weed out the poor performers.
2.  Hire more young people.  NG needs to do a better job of marketing itself to college students.  Most college students today are concerned about finding a job when they graduate, and NG has many jobs to offer IF students obtain the right degree.  These students already have a leg up because of US citizenship requirements for employment in the defense industry, but they don't know it.  We need to reach out to them and let them know there's a great chance of a job at NG if they get the needed skills.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Flexible work life schedule.  Soon to be terminated I'm sure.
cons: Increase every year under Ron Sugar for 9 years.  RIFT'd twice under Wes Bush.  It's not good to know that he was paid $1.5M to come to the falls church area when you're getting laid off.  Regular promotions of VPs and Directors.  Lots of Chiefs and no Indians.  Loss of Recompetes due to this practice. Legacy companies have created a silent war often promoting those from their legacy companies and sometimes resulting in an entire legacy company's staff running an entire group.  Working diligently to eliminate those not from their legacy company.  Couldn't order supplies for two years.  Had to charge all time directly to contracts and no overhead which is basically an insult to your integrity as there are activities everyday that require you to charge to overhead.  Not doing so could result in your being unemployed.  No more NG for me.  No loyalty to this company as after 2006 they no longer have a pension.  Northrop Grumman covers about 2% of health insurance.  They blamed the increase on Obamacare.  It was an amazing company with great benefits.  Now it's just a bunch of crabs in boiling pot. They've brainwashed staff into believing that can't do any better.  "At least you have a job.".  I'm passing this time.
advice_management: Get rid of the over educated staff who do not nothing but talk and burn dollars and bring nothing to the plate.  The Government Contracting environment has changed and Northrop Grumman needs to adjust to the climate.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Environment is satisfying and the people are great. Work is interesting and has highs and lows as expected.
cons: Slowly taking away benefits. Days-off are decreasing and the answer is always, Affordability. Pay Raises are the worst i've seen, about 1-2% a year raise. No bonuses.  Engineering managers need to get trained on how to handle people..
advice_management: Get training on how to manage people. Leadership is a must. Develop those skills.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: All the Overtime you can want.  Friendly work environment.  Indoor work.
cons: Advertise for a 4-10 work week but when you show up you get forced Overtime.  Plant has been on overtime for ten plus years now.  Also, advertise a sign on bonus of $1000 which is hidden behind so much red tape you can never qualify for it.  Better hope you never have a problem with management because HR will cover for them.
advice_management: Clean house at the North Dakota plant, you have management that have absolutely no people skills.  Seems as if you need to live in Stanley to have any hope of getting an upper level job there.  There isn't one native american in any of the higher jobs at site but plant is located in the heart of the reservation.  Very high turnover rate as we don't have enough people to do the work so we get to work OT constantly.  Could go on but I need to go to work.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Good job security. Excellent work opportunities. Good salary when compared with non-defense jobs.
cons: Low yearly raises that do not seem to be merit based. Advancement is difficult. Management plays mind games. Management does not follow through on promises. Smaller defense contractors have better salary and benefits. Hiring process seems random and convoluted.
advice_management: Stop lying.

- Domestic Partner Benefits

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Good pay, and promotional opportunities
cons: Government contracting is a silly business

summary: "They claim big proposals and big ideas but nothing comes to fruition"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good benefits, great location. Not a bad commute.
cons: Huge bureaucracy. Nothng will ever progress until it is after the fact.
advice_management: I don't think I can change management. They are already ingrained into the system.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I work with some of the best and brilliant minds in the business.
cons: Raises over the last few years have been extremely weak, and have not kept up with inflation.
advice_management: I realize it is important to take care of the stock holders and upper management, but we also need to make sure lower level workers are taking care of as well.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Good benefits - health, 401k
Generally good pay and compensation - as always, depends on the manager
Flexible time (unofficially)
Compassionate - accommodates an aged workforce - will never fire (only lay-offs)
Assigned tasks are really easy and simple
Nice co-workers

If you've got drive and lots initiative, you can do well by working hard and most importantly doing other people's work or doing work that others didn't think could be done.  Just make sure to take credit.
cons:
Extreme lack of technical expertise- can't emphasize this enough.  For every 3 engineers that are knowledgeable will be 7 utterly clueless bodies with the same title and pay-grade.  You'll need to be diligent to stay current with modern technologies on your own time.
Based on legacy/obsolete technologies - error prone, bad software tools - rate of productivity is slow
Culture is generally devoid of any sense of accountability relating to the progress of the overall product.  For example, system engineers can create requirements that don't make sense... all that matters is that they wrote words to describe a capability.  System engineers and testers do not have working knowledge of modern operating systems
Amazing hierarchy of managers - allows for a large body of middle managers that is prone to information mix-ups/spins.  Lack of technical expertise in managers fuels fear of change.
Process-heavy, i.e. lots of meaningless paperwork, suffers chronically from well-known pitfalls of the waterfall process

Don't be fooled.  Making weapon systems doesn't mean it's cutting-edge.  The hardest part of the job is effectively communicating technical issues/solutions to non-technical engineers

summary: "Good entry level job but very bureaucratic company"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: People were very friendly and willing to help me with anything. Management allowed me to experiment and make an impact on the project I was working on.
cons: Work is sometimes very slow and there was a lot of self-learning involved. Average age of employees there was about 30 years older than myself, so not many people to relate to.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Specifically for the IS Sector, the work is very interesting.  We solve the Government's hard problems, so the work is always challenging and interesting.
cons: The current downturn in the defense industry, which is expected to cut budgets by anywhere from 10% to 20%.
advice_management: In a big company it's easy to for people and business units to feel like cogs in a big wheel.  Employees work hard when they feel that the company is investing in them and cares about them, and they are likely to return the favor with a work ethic that is beneficial to the company.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: The opportunity to meet and work with some very nice and professional people.
cons: My position was not looked at as a worth-while position, as a result, I and my fellow Drafters were not given the chance to show what we were able to do. My position was eliminated.
advice_management: Just because a person has a degree, doesn't mean that they know how to do a particular job, but if a person has been doing that particular job for a long period of time, they probably know what they are doing. there is no substitute for experience, really.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: They have a nice cafeteria
cons: To much process to actually design anything
advice_management: There needs to be less of you

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: numerous opportunities due to multiple federal contracts
cons: old fashioned, fear-based management culture; little diversity; work life Unbalance; unethical behaviors tolerated at the management level
advice_management: start employing a two-way performance feedback program so that employees can formally communicate to you how you well or poorly you are doing, and advice on how you can improve your own performance

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros:
-Were very good to their people during aftermath of Hurricane Katrina
-Did annual reviews
-Two week shutdown at Christmas
cons:
-Poorly organized - boss lived and worked in another state and had no idea what we did in production support
-Thought that being located in MS was a reason they could pay people well below industry standards
advice_management:
-Don't allow management to phone it in.  
-Have clear career paths laid out within the company.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Great leadership at this specific site. They treat everyone like a person with their own specific backgroud and expertise. Nobody is judged on their past as much as what you can bring to the table.
cons: The working hours arent bad at all, the only con would be the rare occassion you have to work on a weekend but even then its OT pay.
advice_management: Keep up the great work.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman part-time for less than a year
pros: Decent pay as I was still in high school. Hours were flexible. I basically came and went as I wanted, but didn't accomplish much in the end.
cons: Supervisor didn't really know what he wanted me to do. Had me accomplish several small projects that were a bit boring. In the end, I learned that this was not what I wanted to do. I was the only intern.
advice_management: Try to have more interns and assign them certain projects.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: No one else knows my job.
cons: No back up when out on STD
advice_management: Don't be afraid to give credit where credit is due.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
9/80 schedule
telework once or twice a week for those who live far away
cons:
*Incompetent management
- - They try to come up with all kinds of metrics to measure your work, but the metrics do not accurately measure your performance or justify your existense, and therefore, annual review not necessarily reflects the truth
-- I've worked under different managers through out the years, more than half of them have don't care attitude and out of touch with the employees

*Morale / work ethnic
-- Some employees are not motivated to do work.  Maybe due to low annual raise and incompetent management 
-- Sometimes even out performers feel unmotivated and discouraged because of incompetent management and low incentive

*Lower pay rate for software engineer comparing to the market rate in California

*Reduce benefits from here and there every year.  They even discontinue providing bottle drinking water and just install crappy filter in the drinking fountain.  Yes, it gets to that cheap.

*CEO got 26 million dollar salary in 2011 while laid off a bunch of people in past few years.
advice_management:
The only way to find out who is doing the work is by talking to your employees in person, finding out what they are working on.  Not by simply looking at the numbers!!!
Show appreciation to hard working, motivated, talented employees or they will go elsewhere.

summary: "Demanding company with little reward for hard work"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: In this uncertain time for defense jobs, the current company contracts appear to offer a long-term stable job environment.
cons: High expectations and little incentive to retain top performing employees.  Pay raises and bonuses are virtually identical for all employees, regardless of their level of contribution.
advice_management: Provide better rewards for top performing employees.  Eliminate under-performing employees.  There is currently no threat of being fired for doing a poor job and no incentive to do your job well.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: big company, good benefits, opportunities to move around to different contracts.
cons: since it is a little bureaucratic, moving up may not be based on your skills.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Engineers and former government employees (especially retired military officers) run the show here, as you might expect at a major defense contractor. That said, the company does offer excellent work-life balance with 9/80 schedules and flex time. If you work for the right manager, as in any company, you can set your own schedule as long as you get your work done well.
cons: Senior management doesn't acknowledge the dichotomy (in compensation and in development or advancement opportunities) between those who have that intimate customer connection or technical know-how and everyone else, but it's omnipresent.

summary: "Everything you expect from a big corporation"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The manager I have is nice. Do not work at corporate so do not have any contact with the suits.
cons: Raises below inflation, even for high performers. Raises tied to mythological predictions of poor culture performance of the company, which never match what stockholders are told, and never pan out as the company still rakes it in. Benefits keep dropping. Ridiculous culture where upper management tries to tell engineers that they care, are diverse and other ridiculous ideas while they cut benefits and do not even try to keep up with inflation on raises. Layoff culture. Upper management received obscene benefits and pay packages and reorganizes routinely to increase their pay. And they conduct "anonymous" surveys which are mandatory and not really anonymous. It's really just a big Dilbert strip.
advice_management: Engineers are not that dumb. $$ speaks.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: San Diego is a very nice city in which to work.
cons: Although once a promising corporation in terms of Aerospace, the vision of this company has definately sent it into an unrecoverable nosedive.

summary: "You have to look for the positives... but they are there"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Flexible work schedule, good people, lots of resources and opportunities for education assistance, travel opportunities, respectful work environment
cons: Compensation, sequestration concerns, occasionally dull/repetitive work, IT can be poor, lousy male/female ratio in engineering

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Company has great benefits, good pay, and the managers treat you like a person instead of like a tool that makes them money.  They allow lattitude in career decisions and reward people who go beyond expectations.  The best company I've worked for in my 31 years doing computer work.
cons: This is a large company, so there are requirements that are necessary from regulations the government puts on companies.  One example: I never would have any reason to export anything, but still had to complete annual export control training.  Once the company lost the contract I was on, they didn't have anything else local to my home.  They offered to move me to the DC or Atlanta areas for postions they had there, but I couldn't move as I have family in NC.  I am within an hours drive to Raleigh, RTP, and Ft. Bragg, yet they had no openings.  I urged them to bid on DoD work, but their response was that's a different division.
advice_management: Bid on more data work in the Raleigh, RTP, and Ft. Bragg areas.  There's lots of opportunities for contracts, and being a great company, they could retain employees.  Keep up the great work training managers to treat the workers at client sites as people.  Keep rewarding people who go the extra mile.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Large company can move you around if you need to. They have good benefits and flexible time off. Good orientation and onboarding program.
cons: Government contract dependent and could lose federal funding. Management structure is a little confusing.
advice_management: Keep up the good work and continue getting employee feedback via surveys.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: 9/80 schedule, good benefits, fun people
cons: Working with the government, job based heavily on Political situations. Once in promotions and raises are slow and unrewarding.
advice_management: Reward your internal employees 1-2% raises do not retain talent

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Stability, mature departments.  Established sow's that are clear to follow.  Success is meticously defined.  Peaks of busy times, valleys of slower paced weeks.
cons: Political (where isn't?), tend to value consultant recomendations vs. employee recomendations...though that might be a good thing.  Not too many cons from my point of view.
advice_management: Continue to solicit and welcome ideas and feedback.

summary: "Typical Aerospace Defense Company to work at"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Large company with opportunities for movement
cons: Thankless job for long hours and high expectations
advice_management: Listen to; support and appreciate your worker bees.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Northrop grumman provides good benefits and compensation. They have a wide support network that is very accomidating and willing to help.
cons: The jobs can be boring and lack satisfaction. Also the management has a hard time recognizing individuals for their efforts.

summary: "Good pay, good people, felt like a number"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: *Overseas assignment*; good people; good benefits. HR/IT could be challenging to figure out, but had good support stateside. Enjoyed my time there. Never had significant interaction with stateside operations.
cons: Difficult to get overtime; projects are of course on a budget so you feel like a number. Did not feel like I could move up/promote. You would have to move to another location; apply to a higher position. Couldn't figure out the pay scale.
advice_management: Our section's VP did come out and visit; this was nice. Not sure how it is now; he left. Advice - always value your people out there working the contract; they are the ones making you the money at the home office.

summary: "Northgrum overall pretty good to work for"

There are good people in the trenches doing the actual work.

There is not much room for advancement once you get a few years in if you are technical and don't want to go into management.

advice_management: give people at least a small cost of living adjustment every year

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The work I currently do is low stress.  Nothing else good to say about the TS sector.  Other sectors of Northrop Grumman are much better.
cons: Terrible raises - in my 18 years working in this industry, my lowest 3 raises are the 3 years I have worked at Northrop Grumman Technical Services.  They also stopped paying into our pension last year.
advice_management: The raises in the TS sector are hurting morale.  It doesn't help when we see a total compensation package for the CEO above $10 million.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros:
Decent pay and decent benefits. 
Evidence of true diversity - workers of all ages and ethnicity
cons: At this particular location, the only news allowed to play on the break room TVs was Fox. I am a Democrat, so I was less than thrilled. If one of us changed it to CNN, one of the Conservatives always changed it back.

summary: "The people are great, the works steady, the other stuff....not so much."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
The people are hardworking and teams support one another. Everyone knows what to do and how to get the work done. Hard chargers all the way.
Teleworking is encouraged for most non-classified positions
Nationwide presence
If you're used to government speed --  this is the place for you!
cons:
There are so many processes that it makes it impossible to get any work done. Takes days to get approval for a 2 minute job.
Too many layers of non-value add management. 
Non-technical managers making technical decisions which end up wasting money in the long run.
Titles and responsibility with no compensation (except for mgmt positions)
Pushing employees to do more with less, yet laying off those who are doing more.
advice_management:
Need to take a very hard look at the non-value add layers of management in the corporation. RIF  management before you RIF those exempts who keep the wheels spinning. Most technical exempts are comprised of professionals who know what it takes to get the work done. Throwing 4 layers of management into an org is a waste of money. Those managers who came from the trenches and can roll their sleeves up are the ones you want to keep....would probably equal 2-3 of a non-tech manager type.
Managers who are in charge of technical areas should consult their technical SMEs if vendor solutions make sense before making teams waste money and time in evaluating something that is   an already known non-fit. Stop taking vendors' sales pitches as gospel.

summary: "Great Place to stay for the long term, Not a place for quick Promotions"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Family atmosphere, Working with some of the smartest people in the world. Opportunity to learn new things and be on the cutting edge of technology and defense.
cons: No opportunity to move up, very, very slow promotions. If the government pulls funding the program you are on can be cut at anytime.
advice_management: You are losing middle carereer professionals because you pay the older non productive professional for to long and you under pay the lower career professioanls because they are expendable. Spend more time and effort on the middle career professionals, this is your future.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Very positive / employee focused organization
cons: A very large company to pentrate.
advice_management: Do not become removed from your employee base (going beyond direct reports)

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Good company to work for if you can find a good fit....
cons: Unfortunately worked there twice but never found a good fit....was overqualified for both positions.
advice_management: help employes to find a good fit for them and the organization.

summary: "Still learning how to be a professional organization"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Strong engineering prowess and next level aviation design.
cons: Weak mid-level managers and amateur leadership skills on the production level.
advice_management: Pay attention in school.

summary: "Good company headed in the wrong direction"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros:
9/80 work schedule
contributing to national defense
interesting work, products, and projects
(generally) good co-workers
easy to take time off
on-site exercise room
cons:
Lots of corporate double-talk:  ex.  great performance and record bonuses (for the few who get them) then followed by another year of 2% raises because the economy is bad.
Raise cycle switched from 12 to 18 months, makes 2% into 1.3% annually - inflation is higher.
"Harmonizing" benefits to "retain the best talent" with means reduced 401K  match (double-talk).
Steady reduction in benefits over last decade:  insurance, pension, weekly to 2 week pay period.
Company seems to care more about pandering to women, minorities, and homosexuals than anything else, including performance - sorry if you are a straight white male with religious beliefs.
Too much bureaucratic oversight from "Baltimore" which dictates policy for everything but can never be questioned.
Too many disjointed computer systems that don't talk to each other.
advice_management:
Identify and reward talent - you'd have to stop patting each other on the back and pay attention.
End the double-talk.
Get rid of "Baltimore" and their policies - that would save a ton of time & money.
Stop being so cheap to your employees and calling it "affordability" or "harmonization".  
Your "engagement" effort is a farce as employees are not honestly answering the Gallop Q12 to avoid hurting the employee's direct manager.  
"Diversity" means straight white males have limited career path - seriously.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Large company, plenty of opportunity for advancement, smart people abound
cons: Defense Industry is a unstable at times
advice_management: Continue to review talent, provide more rotational opportunities

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: It's Southern California after all

advice_management: get rid of the Matrix structure it creates more chaos than the money it saves

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

pros: Have off every other Friday

In the ELectronic systems sector they just increased raises to 18 months AND the average is 2 percent so you are only getting about 1.3 percent per year. Last year the raises we're only 2 percent.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years

cons: No growth opportunities. Can be an unstable environment. Yearly increases are usually small regardless of your rating. Many re-organizations with little direction.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Highly professional environment, significant challenges.
cons: Company is definitely squeezing employees for profitability

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros:

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: Great place to work, the take care of their employees and want to keep you working for them.  Good benefits including insurance and retirement.  Management knows and cares about employees on all levels.  There is a big focus on ethics and making quality decisions, which is key because some competitors are willing to cut corners to shave costs and win contracts.
cons: Unstable environment because of the nature of the business in working with government contracts.  the pay scale has been reduced and each position has a range that is allowed to be paid in and getting out of that is nearly impossible.

summary: "A great career experience while helping to construct the nation's largest defense platform - Aircraft Carriers."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: I retired recently after almost 35 years.  I worked the entire time at Newport News Shipbuilding which NG spun off as a separate corporation.  Working at NNS allowed me to have multiple careers in various disciplines while remaining in one location while making above average salary and benefits.  Your potential is only limited by the restraints you place on yourself.  NG and NNS were always open to trying a different route if you were not having success on your current path.  You just had to ask and support your rationale for the change.
cons: Promotion above the supervisor and manager level are limited simply due to fewer available high level positions.  If you have your sights set on being a Director, Vice President or CEO, your odds become very slim after age 35 unless you have become one of the "chosen few".   If you have to ask yourself whether you are or aren't, then you aren't.
advice_management: Provide a larger non-managerial advancement path for those not able to reach senior management positions.  You need more "fellow" positions.

summary: "So far, I like what I've seen"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year
pros: People are helpful in acquainting new hires with current projects.  IT support is better than average (still somewhat clunky as with any megacorp).  Workspace is comfortable and I have access to everything I need to do my job.
cons: Cubicles.  Even the management gets cubes, which makes for an egalitarian environment, but I would preferred shared offices (2 or so to a room, with a door you can close when you feel like it).

summary: "Northrop was a great company to work for.  You had many opportunities for advancement."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great Salary and working conditions.
cons: None that I can think of.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: This company is wonderful, they take great care of their employees...managers seem to really care about their employees.
cons: Contacting world is tough, often you feel trapped as a contract employee so getting into some type of upward mobility can be tough.
advice_management: Look at your employees that are filling contracting roles and see how you can mentor or guide their careers within the organization.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Company has fair pay and good benefits.  Not much contact or interaction with Corporate.  Policies promote diversity and inclusion for employees.
cons: Limited opportunities at the current location.

summary: "Northrop Grumman had exceptional pay and opportunity for growth"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: The divisions were decentralized and the pay was great.
cons: Management expected long hours and invested little time in automating manual processes

summary: "I have had wonderful opportunities, and solid management with excellent accountability."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Constant drive to improve quality and efficiency; industry-leading emphasis on ethics and standards; great training opportunities; flexible work schedules and work locations depending on the specific job.
cons: Can't think of any - I'm sure other parts of the company have issues that my sector doesn't.
advice_management: Stay objective in your evaluation of your people - don't be quick to judge based on one thing you see/hear - give your people the benefit of the doubt, and they will respect you.

summary: "A good place to start a career but a lot of luck is necessary to reach the best programs and upper echelon."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros:
As a large company it provides various opportunities for engineers early in their careers to try out different roles and a position that fits with both their strengths and personality.  The company is involved in full life-cycle product development from inception to customer delivery to maintenance so it is possible to participate in multiple stages of a product's path to creation.

Those who perform well and aggressively seek out opportunities can find a rewarding career at Northrop.  Once you exit the company it is a large and known company on your resume to point to in future interviews.
cons:
Access to the best opportunities requires a combination of luck and ninja networking tactics to get noticed by senior engineers or program managers. 
Top performers who are not vocal about their career aspirations can find themselves stuck on a project and with a depressed salary.
Performance reviews are administered by a manager that meets with you at most twice a year.  The review manager is a different individual then the employee's direct supervisor (likely an engineer) and program manager.  The advancement process can seem slow and linear to the ambitious but this is common in most large corporations and not specific to Northrop.
advice_management:
Streamline the process for approval of research projects and submission for outside publication.  The performance review process should be administered by a direct supervisor of the employee.  A manager that meets with an employee once or twice a year is likely not in a position to recognize or advocate for top talent.

Modify the advancement process for engineers so title and pay is tied more towards performance, ability, and future prospects than to class year and graduate degrees.

Reduce the layers of management and bureaucracy between the engineers and senior management.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: Good benefits; lots of opportunities to work on pretty cool stuff that benefits the US military (and others)!  If you're willing to relocate, NG has lots of opportunities across the company, and seems to do a good job of enabling employees to move to a new job/place.
cons:
- As a defense contractor, NG follows the highs and lows of defense work -- right now defense is shrinking, as seen by lots of defense contractors (Lockheed Martin, NG, Raytheon, etc.) having layoffs. 
- If you want to work on cool commercial stuff, a defense contractor isn't the place.
- For software developers, not a lot of decent process in place across the company, nor decent training company-wide for developers.

summary: "A large company with lots of change and opportunities"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Big company benefits, opportunties, word-class products and services, geographically dispersed, teleworking opportunities, long-term career options, and very professional culture.
cons: Constant reorganzation, impacted by federal spending, sometimes works like small companies within one big company, sometimes not seen as an individual.

summary: "Great learning experience at a tough time in the defense industry."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Freedom to do a variety of engineering tasks within my discipline
cons: Several rounds of layoffs in the past few years.
advice_management: People matter as much as the bottom line.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: great company to work for, lots of possibility for growth and movement considering they have offices all over the world.
cons: I have no cons to report.
advice_management: None

summary: "Not the place for folks with ambition/vision"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Good work/life balance.  Allows for flexible work hours.  Education assistance is available with training on and off site.
cons: Bureaucratic and slow to promote achievers.  Management overall lack leadership.  Currently in a declining industry for the next ten years.  Projects/programs can be severely hampered by government auditors.
advice_management: Give more power and accountability to lower management.  Discision making is too high up to be timely and effective, causing lower to middle management to become bureaucratic administrators rather than leaders.

summary: "Good inital job but not a long term career place"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros:
Technically challenging work
Good mentoring available
Good people to work with, no jerks
cons:
Minimal career growth.  Easy to get pigeonholed
Worst working environment I've seen.  One large bull pen for 200+ engineers makes it very difficult to work.
Better pay in the commercial side.  
Came from a different sector in Northrop to the Aerspoace sector and pay was 30% less for the same skillset.

summary: "It's a great company to work for."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great benefits, great salary, work with great people.  I have been able to use corporate aircraft for my personal use when needed, in conjunction with other executives.
cons: Some of the management is a little out of touch.  The vacation policy is a little out of whack, even though they are generous with vacation time, per se.

summary: "Great place to start out, however once you get some experience you need to move on…"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros:
- Chance to move around and work on different projects
- Great job security (i.e. if competent, then low risk of losing your job)
- I always like to say, "Northrop is a great place for a job, but not a career."
cons:
- Poor communication (very little information flows down from management)
- Poor management (company seems very interested in promoting engineers that make horrible people managers)
- Reactive not proactive (company reacts to market, rather than define it)
- Company does not value employees (few promotions, lower salaries, etc.).  If you want valued, then go to a smaller company where your actions directly impact the company.

summary: "Used to be a great company, now is terrible.  It is so terrible I am 29 and took a voluntary layoff!"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I worked in procurement and the people were great (not management though).  Also there is a bar down the street to have a couple beers at lunch so you can get through the day.  Pay and benefits were ok.
cons: Basically everything.  The company still thinks they are in the 80's. If you are a young person you will not be a manager for 30 years.  Way too many levels of management and I do not know how most of these managers were hired.  If you have drive and ambitious then say goodbye to it.  Nothing is efficient, you have to get a signature for anything you do.  Management thinks they know all and will not listen to the low level peasants of the company.  There is a reason why Boeing and Lockheed are ahead of Northrop.  Once most of the good old boys club of Northrop retires then maybe it will improve.  If you are lazy and want someone to make terrible decisions for you then this is the company for you.
advice_management: Stop laying off lower level employees and start laying off management.  Whatever your first instinct is then do the opposite!

summary: "I solid set of peers with high levels of knowledge and experience, but little corporate regard for employees."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Lot's of exposure to interesting products and design activities.  Large base of highly skilled and engaging engineers willing to share their knowledge with peers and juniors.
cons: Overworked with little concern for overall well being both as an individual or employee.  Poor benefit and compensation package.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great training among smart people who are cohesive and focues on their target markets (customers, employees and shareholders).
cons: Too many late nights and weekends.  Vacation available but the peer environment does not foster taking time away - besides it takes forever to catch up if you go away even for a week.  Gotta remember and enforce unplugging yourself.
advice_management: Provide a stand-in for BD leaders.  It's important to have us recharge our batteries so we are most effective.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years

cons: No contact or communication with management.  No chance for advancement. Had to bring own office supplies to work, Northrop Grumman did not supply them. Managers have no clue.
advice_management: Need better communication and sharing of information.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years

Upper management seems more concerned with making sure that nothing peeks over the edge of the cubes, buying large screen tv's for the reception area than with improving by offering items such as training (not in the budget) or raises (Not even cost of living).  Since there is little work, there is also no room for growth or upward mobility.
advice_management: If you want to keep people from defecting to other companies you might want to change your priorities.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Your work revolves around state of the art aerospace/defense projects. Access to a laboratory environment. Programs are very stable and can offer a long and rewarding assignment.
cons: Pay is significantly lower than software engineers make in commercial industries. Like most defense contractors, Northrop Grumman seems to be ~10 years behind the trend when it comes to process, technology, and management style. Programs can be top heavy, with layers of management and overrun with stubborn "senior" engineers who refuse to retire.
advice_management: Remove a layer of management from both the project and functional organizations. Identify top performing talent and pay them to stay.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years

I am working with high end systems, current programs and standards, supporting customers who have very high expectations. I am super pleased with how hands on, and challenging this position is.
I also know that my job is somewhat portable, if I need to move for some reason, or if I want a change of pace, I can look for another Northrop job, and transfer rather than go job hunting and deal with the uncertainty of searching for a new position.
cons: I really can't think of anything that I would call a con, unless you are a person who does not like working for a large corporation. In which case Northrop would definitely not be for you. But if that is not a deal breaker, then I highly recommend working here.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for less than a year

cons: Unfortunately, like all government contractors, the work comes and goes with the whims of the contract. Overturn in personnel is high, and is not unusual for any defense contractor.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Benefits are quite good.  Compensation is adequate for the location.  HIstorically the opeartion was Sperry Marine and the employees take pride in thier products and results of operation.  This organization (NG Charlottesville) can be an excellent career stepping stone if you are willing to play the NG game.
cons: Top management tends to want employees to give all and then expect little in return.  Thus work/life balance is quit bad.  Middle managment operates via intimidation.  Workpace can be what may be considered hostile at times.  Senior management believes that the only good ideas come from NG Sector.
advice_management: Respect your people and and involve them, they have a history that can make your future better.  And remember, without the people, the shareholders don't make a dime.  The people make NG, not managers.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years

cons: Almost impossible to advance out of a billable position.  Once they had you brining in a check from the customer, they did not want you to leave for another position within the company.
advice_management: Allow your employees to develop full careers instead of thinking of them purely as a piece of a contract vehicle.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years

*Great environment for those who like loose management (not the case 100% of the time though)
*Good benefits (Education reimbursement, 401K, health, etc)
*The company as a whole is great - fantastic CEO
*Good facilities
*Many opportunities to learn from knowledgeable people
*Fascinating work
cons:
*Very, very little accountability; those who were a detriment to the company weren't dealt with very well or at all
*Very little acknowledgement for those who performed in an outstanding manner. Generally in the form of "Lets just make everyone feel good" rather than pointing out stellar contributors
*Multiple reductions in force over the last couple of years, >50% downsizing in my division
*Poor communication between management and the production floor
*Poor design for manufacturing
*Poor designs in general many times
*Military contract dependant

It appeared to me that recent reorganizations seem to have left no single corporate entity with an interest in growing the business in Aurora. Raytheon is eating your lunch.

summary: "Small division didn't allow for as much upward mobility as I'd prefer."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Great group of people to work with. The 9/80 schedule was awesome, allowing us to take every other Friday off. But I think it was all just a sham to get us to work more hours during the week and give us another opportunity to come in to get work done. Sneaky, huh?
cons: Since most projects come from the government and military, there can be lots of red tape which slows things down like crazy. Work really depends on what's available, which can be an extremely bad thing.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time
pros: Northrop works to keep people employed, moving them to different programs when current programs wrap up.
cons: Keeping your salary advancing requires that one only stays there for 3-4 years max before moving to a different company.  Same as all aerospace companies.
advice_management: Spend more time planning and tracking detail-level work.  Do it carefully, and have it done by someone who really knows the task, not just whoever you can get a team to give up.

summary: "Robust transition experience from senior military officer to mid-level manager in a major corporation"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: You are hired for your demonstrated ability to get the job done, company gives you significant room for professional autonomy which not giving you too much room to cause serious financial harm, I came into corporate world expecting to be "spoon fed" training on how to perform at the PM level and being a profit and loss entity individual training dollars are tight so you are left with a lot of OJT or self training.
cons: Too little resources for new hires (managers) to get acquainted with the corporate's tools and procedures
advice_management: N/A

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: health benefits were very good and the company has on site health clinics every 6 months or so. Cholesterol and blood pressure screening for free.
cons: Not too green thinking or eco friendly, insisted on using fluorscent bulbs and when asked if we could turn them off overhead they would not allow.
advice_management: Be proactive in bringing back employees after contract ends. Be more up front about contract end dates and not secretive. Use more telecommuting, people traveled great distance to come to work and were tired after a horrendous commute in DC area. Make use of NG buildings close to the employees home instead of having them travel across town and pass an NG building on their block.

summary: "Great people and life-balance; morale is poor and declining"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 8 years
pros: Flex time is available, and is encouraged. People are very skilled and the talent is high.  You learn a lot!
cons: Morale has grown poor over the past 3 years.
advice_management: Improve communication to employees so they understand why the company is going through changes.  They are smart people and will understand.

summary: "Positive Experience - Well Run Organization, Excellent Legacy, Cutting Edge Technology"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Educational Opportunities for life long learning are highly encouraged and supported.
cons: Limited career growth, salary increases plateau (essentially amount to a COLA),  which barely keep pace with inflationary pressures -driving the perception that you are moving backwards annually.
advice_management: Hold on to your talent...There are many incentives that can be leveraged but the one that always speaks the loudest in terms of an employees perception of value to the organization are wages. Even in today's economic uncertainty their is no sound logic in investing in your talent pool only to have them ensure your competition succeeds.

summary: "Decent benefits, low raises, "you are lucky to have a job mentality" until you put in your notice to leave."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Large company and you can get lost in the sauce.  Benefits are standard but are decreasing never increasing.
cons: Medical coverage cost went up every year, raises were low, does not like to move contractor employees to new positions, would rather hire from outside.  They have a lot of people that are "stuck" working there as they can't find better without losing accrued leave time.
advice_management: If someone qualifies for a different position, let them move to it rather than make them stay in a position that drives them to leave the company.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Good company to work for.

summary: "Great for short term plan and fresh from College  -- longevity is not rewarded!"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: It is really hard to find them...
cons: It's obviously called WORK for  a reason!  Not that I mind hard work... I don't!  I gave my 150-200% all the time!  But it always seemed the more you did, the more they gave you... without any compensation or thanks in the process.  Most of the employees are being stretched too far-- Ones with good work ethic are undermined and railroaded .  Too many favorites... the rest will die trying.  And nothing seems to change. Past 3-4 yrs of annual layoffs really undermine employee morale.. which is still at an All-time low!!
advice_management: Too much middle managment still... even with all the layoffs! Certain depts still maintain the Good 'ole Boy mentality! Take a good look at who really does the work.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: good pay good people good company
cons: reliant on the government for contracts
advice_management: Lead by example

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Great group of people to work with - military friendly - a lot of room for advancement. This organization has a lot of room for growth although it is well established - but as always - it's all about knowing the right people.
cons: Politics of working for a Government contractor include government red-tape. This means your contracts may be cut short at any time. Be sure to get in to several projects and have your foot in the door at all times.
advice_management: Ensure your top engineers that their jobs are guaranteed regardless of what contracts may be expiring soon.

summary: "Company with a defense-only mindset, nice people, reasonable pay"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Pay is acceptable for the services rendered.  People are nice and seem family oriented unless they are one of the "workaholic" class that exists herein.  Many people are genuine and enjoy helping others.  This is a good place to work but expect to move around if you want your pay to remain commensurate with your worth and responsibility.
cons: No good deed goes unpunished here.  If you work hard, you get ALOT more work.  If you don't work hard you can limp along until retirement by doing the bare minimum.  For those of us who want to contribute and advance it can be frustrating securing a raise and moving up, even when a graduate degree is obtained.  Pay increases are pretty sad and don't even keep up with inflation which is why most employees I know have moved out of the company and returned after a few years.
advice_management: Focus on not demanding more than 50 hrs/week of employees, especially the talented high-performing ones.  We will move on to better environments as opportunities present themselves frequently.  Raises and advancement after graduate school is completed should be substantial and enough to where employees don't have to wait the 12 months required after graduation only to kick the door open and receive the raise they have earned.  Stay positive and diversify the company into commercial markets to weather defense cuts.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: The company has great Benefits and it is a joy to work with them. The work hours were flexible. I worked with a real team of professionals.
cons: There is nothing that I can say against the company. Even though my position was terminated due to BRAC they did attempt to put me on other positions with the company. However, they had none available in my field of employment.
advice_management: Assist employees as they attempt to set career paths. Some need more guidance than others.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than a year
pros: Northrop Grumman is a leader in the aerospace industry.  The company is growing and treats it's employees with respect and is very professional.  I find that nearly everybody that I work with enjoys working with NG and many have been here their entire careers.
cons: Somewhat difficult to get an overall handle on what the company is doing regarding what programs.  However, this is due to security reasons.  I would like more ability to look ahead and plan career growth.
advice_management: Keep employees informed of changes that will affect them.  Provide more feedback on job performance and expectations.

summary: "No place for technical people.  Do not waste your time."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Decent salary and benefits.  Full education reimbursement.
cons: The management makes technical decisions without consulting the technical staff.  The management takes no responsibility for their actions and retaliates against employees that speak up or question their decisions.  Northrop Grumman corporate refuses to acknowledge any of the problems at this branch and will not take any action.    There have been 3 rounds of "reduction in force" with no reduction in management.  I expect this place to be closed in 2 years with the way the management is running things.  Soon there will be 1 employee and 300 managers.  Sound like a good idea to me.  Many good people have left voluntarily due to the incompetence of management.
advice_management: Clean house and start over with a new set of managers.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Ok pay and good benefits such a medical, dental, and vision.  Also, they offer free membership to sittercity and weight watchers.  On-site eatery and medical department.
cons: Unstable work environmnet, low morale, poor corporate culture.  It is very difficult to move up unless you know someone and you are a minority.
advice_management: Right now it is a very unstable work environment with major layoffs.  It would be nice if more information was given to the employees.  Also, morale is very low due to the cut throat corporate culture.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: The company uses cutting edge technology throughout and offers expertise in all areas.

advice_management: Share the business vision with design folk consistently.

summary: "Good time while it lasted, but then the world went to poop"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Many high-tech programs.  Used to be good benefits (going downhill).  Many opportunities to find out "what you want to be when you grow up - but you must look for them to find them
cons:
Management is strictly out for its own.  Functional management (generally speaking) does not do a good job looking out for their people.  Program management tends to treat people poorly.  When things go wrong, they blame others loudly.  When things go well, they are short of praise.

One of the reasons I left was because other managers told me that I would not succeed in a management path, because I was the wrong sex/color.  How can I keep working for a place that's told me that?
advice_management: Take care of your people better - programs aren't succeeding because of the PM's, but in many cases, in spite of them.
