summary: "Northrop Grumman is a great company, but there are areas to avoid!"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Northrop is a great company that treats its employees well and provides excellent benefits and good working conditions.  They pay at or just above market value, and the current yearly raise is roughly 3%.  There is a legacy pension plan (in most of the sectors) for employees that have been there a long time.  For newer employees there is a reasonable 401K matching program and a generous company funded savings program.  The holidays vary based on sector with Electronic Systems and Corporate having the best holiday schedule, followed by Aerospace Systems, then Information Systems and Technical Services.  Vacation and sick time are combined into accrued PTO (Paid Time Off), and the allotment is standardized across the corporation and based on the number of years you've been employed by the company.  They have a good tuition reimbursement program.  There is also an excellent employee discount program that includes supplier price for US auto manufacturers, Home Use Program for Microsoft products, special pricing on GE appliances, and many others.  For positions with travel requirements, travel arrangements are typically made by the employee through the company approved online travel site, except for international travel which must be booked over the phone.  Business class travel is allowed for international travel where the total travel time including layovers in a 24-hour period exceeds 12 hours.  The typical federal travel requirements (lowest available fare, per diem rates, etc.) apply to selecting flights and hotels.
cons: Northrop is an engineering company at heart.  It's very process-oriented, and if you don't have an engineering degree, officer's retirement from one of the military branches, and/or high-level acquisition experience with one of the major customers, it's tough to work your way up the ladder.  The online expense report tool the company uses is...well, let's just say it's not friendly.  There are groups within the company that should be avoided at all costs for various reasons.  In some cases, they are career black holes.  In other cases their management is abysmal.  In rare cases, the two coincide and result in a working nightmare.  If you're interviewing, ask to speak to some or the people that would be your teammates/counterparts (alone if possible).  Find out how long they've been in their positions, if they're happy with their position, career prospects and management, and what happened to the person who was in the seat you're interviewing for.  If you end up in a bad seat within the company, there are no internal safeties - it will likely be tough to get out of that group without switching companies, and the yearly review process can be manipulated to make even a stellar employee look like a flunky.
advice_management: There should be better mentorship and a formal grooming program for future management.  Also, an employee review of their direct management should be included in the yearly review process.  The employees' review of their management should account for a substantial portion of the manager's total review score.  Most of the management at NG is great, but there are some that really damage NG's ability to hang onto good employees and have the potential to become serious legal liabilities for the company.

summary: "The work is challenging, but it's a good place to work."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: I love that the work we do is difficult and challenging, because it makes solving the problems more rewarding. The benefits are some of the best in Oklahoma, in some ways even better than what you'll find at Chesapeake or Devon. Work-life balance is encouraged here, even if you're aggressive in advancing within the company. The company does pay well, even if it doesn't always feel like its enough.
cons: Like all work at defense contractors, work can come and go in a blink of the eye. Even programs on contract with high need are subject to cuts or cancellations, especially given the environment in Washington right now. The defense industry is an odd cross roads where it is trying to shrink, which means layoffs and budget cuts, but at the same time trying to get younger. This creates unique opportunites for those lucky enough to survive cuts, but challenges as well in that there is more work than can be done in a normal work week. At times it feels like the conpensation falls short of the work done, though the pay is still good for Oklahoma.
advice_management: Management does a good job recognizing people who work hard, continue to do so. Be more aggressive though in pushing for top performers.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
If you know the right people you can go far.
Average salary for the skill sets.
Average benefits, and like most major companies they are going up in price and down in value.
There are cutting edge groups, but you have to search them out.
cons:
Too much management spread over a large and diverse product set. The current (2012) hierarchy adds three to four layers of upper (expensive) management between program execution and corporate leadership, with no defined value added to the final product. 
Constant reorganizations undo development of relationships and process efficiencies for both individuals as well as the organizations changed.
In ability of management at any level to approve investment in a program upfront to reduce costs later on. The common approach to risk management is identify and ignore until it is an issue.
advice_management:
Stop trying to communicate with your workforce through surveys, and actually communicate with them.
Flatten the organization. Make management a priority, instead of trying to sideline it to a 20% job. 
Make sure your management team can actually manage. Employees are rated annually by their managers (and themselves), add a process for employees to rate their manager.
Responsibility delegation is good; but do not assume that because you delegated a job to someone and that job was completed that: A. the delegate had any part in its success; and B. that completion = success.
Understand that every request made at the top of the management chain will “snowball” as it rolls down the organization, taking time and resources from already strapped projects. 
Do not ask for a monthly status report on specific programs if you are not going to come up to speed on each of those programs; and if you are, then cut out the two levels of management in between that are no longer adding value.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: The benefits are good and you are surrounded by good people.  I personally liked my manager who seems to be interested in improving the skills of his employees.
cons: Sometimes you are not compensated well.  Accessing Northrop Grumman's websites are very time consuming.  For example filling out my time card takes 5 minutes when it should only take 1.  There are many errors with their internet websites which prevent employees from accessing their information.
advice_management: Continue to be honest with your employees and continue to provide employees with means of improving their skills through tuition reimbursement and certifications.

summary: "The job was good/challenging until the defense budget got slashed."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: The work was interesting and challenging.  I worked there 35 years.  The pay was maybe above average and if you worked hard you got ahead.
cons: The defense industry is cyclic and right now it is in a very bad position because of out of control government spending.
advice_management: My advice to management is to diversify more than you have.  You are going to have many more layoffs until things get better.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Technology and type of work
cons: Low pay for location.  Doesnt take past experience into the equation.
advice_management: As a whole good.  Specific, not really helkpful

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Relaxing, not a lot of pressure (you are still take a breath!).  You are given the time to learn the things you need to do your job correctly.
cons: Compensation not as high compared to commercial companies (high tech).  However, the is understandable because of the relaxing environment.  You are pay enough to work 40 hours a week, but not 50+ hours a week as in other high tech (commercial) companies.
advice_management: A great place to work.  Just bring in more younger employees to loosen the "tight" environment in the office!

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Pay, location, weather and free parking.
cons: Too many to list but here are but a few: loud unprofessional office environment, no training budget, no local IT group, management that rules by fear and intimidation.
advice_management: Stop manageing to a limited set of metrics. Stop using fear and intimidation as your primary motivational tools.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Transfer opportunities within the company. Good benefits for education (100% with some monetary annual caps for the different sectors - ES is the best sector for those benefits by far). Comprehensive health plans with a few options to choose from.
cons: They are laying people off left and right. I have been there two years so far and they have had 4 layoff with a possibility of two more to come this year (2012).
advice_management: Listen to your employees and invest in a younger, more dynamic and cultural diverse work force.

summary: "Environment abounds with inefficiency and complacency. Unqualified management. Outdated technology."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Good benefits package
Job security
Low stress
Above average compensation
cons:
Management heavy
Many leaders are narrow-minded, short-sighted, lack the drive and skills to be relevant and competitive
Environment stymies innovation and improvement, change
Frequent awards for insignificant or irrelevant work diluted effect of praise and recognition
advice_management: Trim dead-weight from both management and employee tiers. Encourage, recognize, reward those who innovate. Expand into new markets. Devise and commit to road map that brings company back to relevance and in touch with modern business models and technologies.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: The work is very interesting and the pay and benefits are excellent.
cons: It's a secret environment so information is tightly controlled.
advice_management: Keep doing what you are doing.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Excellent 401k, Credit Union, and Medical plans. Decent retirement/separation packages. Onsite fitness center and fitness classes. Excellent tuition assistance.
cons: Incompetent and undeserving middle and upper management. Poor strategy planning that causes unnecessary time constraints and inefficient use of resources. Onsite HR is worthless. Promotions are only given to those that are in the right circle. It's hard to get recognized for hard work and talent unless you know the right person.
advice_management: Take a good look at your upper & middle management, a lot of them are very incompetent and lack management skills. You will lose some of the most talented and smartest employees, if you 1) work them to death, 2) don't recognize and compensate their achievements, 3) challenge them, and 4) continue promoting undeserving people to management roles.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great environment, working in the Structural Integrity Department, the cubicles are fashioned into groups to facilitate collaborative efforts. Engineering staff was more than helpful to aid prospective engineering students.
cons: Being a fairly old company, they have been transitioning into the digital realm, but a lot of the older data is still in physical paper copy in libraries.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Fair Pay and rewarding results
cons: Eyewash and procedures built to cover corporation and not facilitate actual job at hand.
advice_management: Work smarter and not harder, develop realistic production scheduling, stop working your best employees to death let them know it is OK to have a home life.

summary: "Good place too work, future stability dependent on brutal parent (Baltimore)."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Lots of support from peers. Great talent and knowledge available.
cons: Victim of business decisions of parent company in Baltimore.
advice_management: Become independent of Baltimore. No power to do so.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Good place to work. Lots of challenging and interesting programs.
cons: Company is very large, and management seems disconnected from everyone else.
advice_management: Connect more with your employees

summary: "Inconsistent workflow and limited opportunity. Flexible schedule and good benefits."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: There are great benefits and flexible schedule.  Most of the employees are friendly and willing to share their knowledge with new engineers.
cons: The dynamic nature of upper management doesn't seem to trickle down to lower management or engineers. Lots of stagnant employees.
advice_management: When bringing in new talent, have a plan for them that extends past a couple of months. Young people get bored quickly.

summary: "The company has declined badly and now focuses on shareholder profits, with no job security for technical people."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
- There are some cool projects to work on. My current project is great and is the only reason I am still with the company.
- Pay seems to be competitive with other large companies like Northrop Grumman.
cons:
- The company has changed from having a long-term focus and developing its employees as a vital resource to just hiring and firing whoever they need for a project. There is no job security and you will be laid off as soon as your project is complete.
- The benefits used to be okay, but the company is cutting our benefits (like paid vacation) to save money. This is disturbing since the company is profitable and the senior officers are paid millions of dollars a year, while the actual engineers are treated worse each year.
- It's become difficult to get money or other resources to do research or pursue technology that might benefit a customer. The company doesn't invest much in research anymore.
- The company has become less agile over the last few years and now it's almost impossible to get a computer that's ideal for your work needs or to get permission to install needed software like VMware Workstation. The IT and other departments now make their own jobs easier at the expense of those of us who actually do the engineering work for our customers.
advice_management:
My immediate management is competent and caring. The levels above that, all the way to the top, appear to be either unsure what to do or concerned only with saving their jobs and profiting themselves and the shareholders. No one I know feels valued by the company and we all know we can be laid off at a moment's notice no matter how exceptional we are.

Northrop Grumman has a toxic work environment. Many of the best people n my operating unit have already left and more are leaving soon. I am still with the company only because I like working on my current team and doing great things for our customers, and my colleagues feel the same way. If our project ends, we will all move to new companies.

This is a challenging time for Northrop Grumman, but the senior management's approach to improving the company's profitability has driven away most of the most talented engineers in my operating unit and those of us left will leave if/when our project ends. I'm not sure how to fix this situation, but I can tell you that reducing benefits and making it harder to do our jobs with increasing bureaucracy is not the way forward. Also not helpful is the fact that when you moved the headquarters from California to Virginia, you paid (or overpaid) all the expenses of senior management, who already make millions of dollars a year. When a great engineer sees that the senior management makes ridiculous amounts of money to make dubious decisions, and that the future of Northrop Grumman depends entirely on questionable forces out of his control, he begins to look elsewhere. The Engagement surveys are also a slap in the face of the line workers. It should be obvious why people are becoming less engaged over time and having managerial work groups will not improve the situation.

summary: "Working for a Giant Corporation is what you'd expect"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Good salary compared to similar jobs, and if you want, you can get away with doing absolutely zero work or being completely incompetent.
cons: Your coworkers will often be lazy idiots.  There is endless bureaucracy, nothing gets done, and you'll never be recognized for your contributions.  If you ever have dispute with the company you have to get a lawyer before they will pay *any* attention to your concern.
advice_management: Fire the useless people, promote the people who actually do work.

summary: "Good job with good benefits and salary."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Above average salary
Pretty flexible schedule. I am able to make my own schedule most of the time.
Good employees to work with
Good Management
Fun
cons:
No room to promote in the job I am in
Inappropriate hiring techniques
Not always fair promotions
Sometimes late hours/overtime

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Good Coworkers, Management that cares, Competitive Salary.
cons: Worst Time-Off in Top 10 Firms, Difficult Prescription Drug Plan, Extremely Poor HR.
advice_management: Increase vacation time - at present it is not competitive, and there is nothing that compensates for it. Fix the dysfunctional relationship with HR and Accounting - at the present it is losing you money and discouraging employees.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Great opportunities to do different stuff, you just have to put yourself out there
Support from upper management about getting more involved in the company and persuing activities
Management is trying to be more "innovative" which is really (slowly) shaking things up (positively)
Internal programs to stimulate employees being empowered to take over their own careers
cons:
If your project ends, you are out of luck.  You have to find your own new position and you are given the same priority as an external employee. (although I think this situation depends on the group)
HR center is worthless, you call for help and they just read back the literature.  No deeper understanding of benefits.
advice_management:
Keep pursuing more modern ways of growing the company.
Find something to do when people have gaps in charge numbers because you can really be loosing great people due to funding issues on projects.
Employees really like getting involved in helping out

summary: "Good overall from my 2 years experience in 2 different sectors with AS being better than TS"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: While some of the program leadership is not managing problems well as a company I feel very well taken care of. I was recently part of a "destaffing" and was relocated quickly to a new program in the same area which turned out to be a better move for myself.
cons: If your good at what you do, you work alot of hours but so far I have been approved for extra pay for those hours but it strains the work/life balance.

summary: "Good Company to gain experience and build a career"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Good Company to work for
Salary is fair
Benefits are very good
cons:
Communication is slow or too-late
no recognition for work well-done
Be careful about getting "pigeon-holed" into a position with no chance of advancement. 
they try to back-end shift-pay into your base salary amount
advice_management:
Start listening to employee concerns. Talk to employees more(in your charge) and promote career advancement rather than always trying to flatten the organization
Allow employees to advance their careers by moving around to gain more experience in other areas which will benefit them and the company

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Work on top programs, with bright people, in an excellent work environment
cons: Pockets of excellence, and some pockets of surprises.  The good news is word travels fast within the company, so not-so-great middle managers become known. However, when joining as a new-hire, it's daunting to determine if you'll be working for an ace manager, or a sociopath.
advice_management: Minor suggestion - better feedback system on middle managers.  Where there are constant complaints, there may be a management problem.  High turnover in groups is also an indicator.

summary: "Good company with ability to be great but carrer is limited if you do not have friends at higher levels to help you"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Good Benifits as far as profit sharing and other items like health care coverage etc...

Personally I have been able to get off as needed for personal  reasons so that has always been a good thing to have when needed. management is good in that area
cons:
Program Managers make unrealistic decisions based on profit and not reality of how the program actually works at ground level or towards customer needs..
They expect unlimited hours as in monitoring emails at 9:30PM for 6:30AM directions the next day and this happens  time and time again. When do you suppossed to be off work? Mostly applies to salary staff. Many workers work 60 a week minimum and some upwards to 80...a week!!

Management places work leads and and other non-management staff in management types of situations where you have no authority over who they ask you to correct lets say in a employee behavior problem scenario or work not getting work done scenario.

Seems like the same top 15 people get promotions and change jobs while the rest can interview 10 times for 10 different positions but you never are qualified to receive an offer. Basically if your manager does not help you advance then you cannot on your own talent alone. I say this not just me but noticed this many times in our peer group. Interviewing for 3-4 times for a job and there are only two from your program and they then hire the 3 candidate  from the outside. you are better off to come from outsie then to be hired from within.
advice_management:
Profit, while a good thing, should not be the overall and only objective when doing business. Customer satisfaction should be considered because of customer is satisfied then profit will come.
Middle program management should let lower levels openly communicate with upper management. Even though we may not be at a higher managment level many are still engineer's, PHD's and professionals with many many years of experience that could be  useful if used as shared resource rather than ignoring your opinions all together..

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Provides a security clearance. Made some great friends among my peers. Intramural sports leagues and regular social outings. Great health benefits. OK 401K plan (you put in 4% and they'll match 2% max).
cons: Lack of communication and feedback; managers wait until end of year to provide anything meaningful. Employees put into leadership positions without demonstrating any ability to manage people. Far behind the cutting edge. Laid off 800 people 3 times in the past 2 years.
advice_management: Stop laying people off while still giving upper management bonuses. Place an emphasis on providing real feedback monthly, with meaningful goal setting.

summary: "Be ready to sell your soul to get ahead"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: 9-80 schedule & December holiday shut-down
cons: Problems with most Management - Horrible communication, willing to lie to make themselves look good, unethical, hypocritical, immature, irresponsible, and unfair. Hard work is ignored. Money is wasted in ways that are shameful. The work environment kills your spirit. They promote cliquey work environments. Most learn to just go through the motions and not be concerned with doing good work.
advice_management: Spend time identifying the unethical employees and get rid of them.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: E85 was a very family oriented work place.  I enjoyed my time there.  There is always continuous training for the employees.
cons: Compared to other areas, the pay could be increased for the radiologial controls department.  Raised should be based more off of work completed.
advice_management: I loved my management.  I dont really have anything negative to say.  Management has always helped and advised as needed.

summary: "Surrounded by average intellingence yet overpaid people"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: It's very hard to get fired. You get an annual raise ever year 2-4%. Good benefits. It' s a good place if you want to veg and collect reasonable pay for it.
cons: It's equally hard to get a promotion. The laziness of some people is impressive. A very bad place to be if you are an overachiever. Upper mgmt care more about their benefits and power than their people and quality work.
advice_management: If you want to be competitive, find a way to reduce all the director and VP fighting. You must also reduce the HR departments power. The hardest thing will be eliminating the culture the rewards mediocrity and stifles change and progress.

summary: "Compensation is not worth required commitment level"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Halfway decent ecent health care benefits.
cons: Total disregard to work/life balance.

summary: "Lots of red tape, but otherwise a good day to day experience"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Work flexibility (ability to telecommute)
cons: Bureaucracy. Too  much red tape really makes working here a hassle.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: It is a very diverse company.
cons: There are many bias Managers.
advice_management: They should treat all employees fairly.

summary: "NGIT was a fairly decent and reasonable company to contract with."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: The people seemed easy to work with and get along with. After a period of time, It seemed that I was part of the organizational family.
cons: After expending time and money in finding employees, I was only able to obtain contracts with them for 4-5 months, after which time, NGIT wanted to have them convert to their employment. I felt like I was used as a headhunter and I lost some talented employees.
advice_management: Allow contractors to have at least one additional employee for at least one year if possible.

summary: "On the cutting edge of technology, Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems is a great place to work."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems, designs, develops, manufactures, operates, and supports: airborne radar, navigation, electronic countermeasures, precision weapons, airspace management, space payloads, marine and naval systems, communications, biodefense, and government systems.  Great opportunies for employment.
cons: Northrop Grumman as a whole does not seem to have the lobbying power in Washington DC to land the big contracts that other large defense contractors like Lockheed Martin and Boeing always get.
advice_management: Beef up your Business Development teams.

summary: "Not a good time for the industry"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Working in aerospace can be a great experience when government funding is available. The benefits packages are usually some of the best and often included pension plans.
cons: Unfortunately, those heydays are gone. Government funding is scarce and layoffs are aplenty. The pensions have been discontinued for new employees.

summary: "Great company and wonderful people to work with."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great benefits and salary.   Opportunity for wide range of experience.
cons: Company is no longer is able to provide alternate positions when contracts end.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Flexible Schedules - They Would Bend Over Backwards To Allow Employees To Be Off For Appointments, Deaths, Moving, Etc.
Cared About The Welfare Of Their Employees
cons:
Corporate Very Secretive About Company Or Division Status
Benefits Administered Through 3rd Party
Payroll Problems Common & Hard To Get Fixed
Total Failure To Move Employees To Other Contracts When One Ended
advice_management: Northrop Grumman Top Corporate Levels Need To Share More With The Regular Workers At The Lowest Levels So That Everyone Is Informed Of The Company's Status. Technical Support Division Sends Total Idiots To Bid For New Business - Use The "Boots On The Ground" Folks That Know Who To Talk To And How Things Run To Get New Business Started.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
While my headline might seem negative, that's not entirely the case. In some projects, it gives one a great deal of freedom, technically and professionally. It's a great place for learning the technical aspects of the software/firmware trade. This can be a great career start.

For the most part, I've experienced very little micro-management of my assignments, which is a very satisfying way to work.

Additionally, the electrical and software engineers I work with are nearly universally top-rate, and willing to share knowledge.
cons:
Looking back from mid-career as a software engineer, working at Northrop seems to have become a succession of unrelated assignments. Assignments are, understandably, made according to program needs. The rub is that each new assignment means getting started with new management and a new team, which means re-establishing yourself regularly. There's very little team/management continuity.

In sum, it can be very much like working as a contractor after a while. Of course, that may simply be the nature of mid-career engineering everywhere.

Oh, and the review process can be, depending on your individual manager, not very worthwhile.
advice_management: It might help the engagement initiative if there were a bit more continuity in the relationship between staff engineers and management.

summary: "I learned a lot, but there was very little training."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Working for a defense contractor, especially a major powerhouse like NGC, comes with extremely interesting work.  I loved the people I worked with as well.  They were extremely helpful with dealing with suppliers, adjusting to SAP, and with letting me rant about workplace politics.  The HR department was also great about helping with general questions, such as where things were, who to contact for certain questions, etc.  The 9/80 schedule was perfect for an internship as well.
cons: Zero relocation was offered.  I understand that it was an internship, but when two of its major competitors, Boeing and Lockheed Martin, both offer some sort of relocation for the majority of their interns, it's difficult to justify choosing NGC over either of those two companies if one has the option.  It also took me a week for basic computer access and another three weeks for internet access due to the extreme levels of security.  In essence, those were some of the most boring weeks of my life.
advice_management: Offer some relocation for your interns.  I know the majority of them live in Illinois, but you're limiting yourselves and the internship program by not showing willingness to go the extra mile for the intern.  Also, specifically in the purchasing building, start focusing on new hires/interns.  The majority of the building I can see retiring in the next 5-10 years, so unless a major hiring/knowledge sharing initiative is started soon, the purchasing side of the site is going to suffer.

summary: "I enjoyed my time there though there were things which needed improvement"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Interpersonal Employee friendships were good.
Benefits are great.
Pay is good.
cons:
Management kept eye on selling product while not wanting to fix product problems as well as could have been.
A lot of push to sell product rather than correct issues.
Technicians input need to be listened to more than they are.
advice_management: It is important to meet the sales but please listen to the people who have their hands in the product because they know what really needs to be done.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Would be a great place to work when the government is actually releasing contracts.  If not then be prepared for a layoff.  Also the Slidell site is horrendous.
cons: Middle management is often unsupportive and plays favorites.
advice_management: Replace middle management.

summary: "When it's good, it's very good, when it's bad, it's political and unpleasant"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Benefits
Supporting the troops
The other employees
cons:
Politics
Slow to promote
Sectors compete amongst themselves
advice_management: Take care of your good people.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great atmosphere to work in, all superiors were extremely respectful to me, exciting and engaging field to work in with growing opportunities.
cons: Pay is good but not great, seems like advancement may take longer than at other companies but it is definitely possible.
advice_management: Try to make time at least once a week to speak with your subordinates and make sure everything is going well with them.  Managers did this, but directors not as much.

summary: "Company does not act like the 1NG that they promote."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Compensation is very competitive. If you can find the correct program to be on, there may be cutting edge work that will challenge and help you grow.
cons: Those "good" programs that I spoke of? They're diamonds in the rough, especially in Information Technology. You are constantly surrounded by people who are grossly outdated. No matter how much company leadership says they want to bring in young blood to come up with the next great ideas, the young employees typically get stuck doing busy work that effectively stunt their growth as engineers. Good and bad programs aside, Northrop Grumman as a whole does not act like one cohesive company. There is very little communication of opportunities cross company sectors, and more often than not employees are discouraged or blocked from looking towards opportunities in other sectors.
advice_management: You need to do more than offer the company cool aid and above average compensation to keep new young talent. What we crave more than anything is good challenging work in our area of interest. If this is not possible, don't over promise and under deliver.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great work life balance; interesting challenges on the job with all levels of engineering done; decent pay given perks of the work life balance; Flexible hours
cons: Difficult to advance financially or with job titles, forced (usually) minimum number of years of experience before the ability to advance; pay differences between high and low performers are not as large as with other companies; lots of government work means stability but also slow progress of work
advice_management: Incentives to work hard do not exist outside of one's internal passion for doing a good job, that is, pay differentials between high and low performers is not that great, decreasing motivation for one to go the extra mile.

summary: "They've offered less and less in just the 5 years I've been here."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: job is mon-Fri., 7:30 to 4.  no weekends, unless a major event takes place. Pd holidays.
cons: Have taken almost all our benefits away. Stopped matching any of our 401K.Stopped offering Sick Leave with the new contract,  but even took away the ones we had already saved up.
advice_management: ** Needs to be a big improvement on employee and management accountability. A little recognition here and there and  communication would go a long way to improve moral.

summary: "Decent place for the process oriented person"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Decent work / life balance
Individual contributors / Subject Matter Experts can lead - easy to set yourself apart
Pay was reasonable and career growth, while limited, did increase year to year.
cons:
Very very process oriented company.
Decisions on work / contracts left to the discretion of upper management / government - obviously.  
With so many government contracts - work can come and go quickly, must be able to sustain the stress of job insecurity for months at a time, until contracts are finalized.  Limited opportunities in the Northeast, must move for any other interesting work.
advice_management: None

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Working for  a defence contractor gives a person a chance to make a difference to the the war fighter and support their country in this way while making a living.
cons: Computer tools and applications put in place may not make a division a cost efficient place to work.To make emplyees accountable for the bottom line then they need to change the mangemet structure from right now such that these emplyees get to keep their jobs if the General manger gets a bonus for making sales. instead make it an employee run company?
advice_management: Check strategic stratagies for if they are working or not. If they are not working or more costly than expected then don't keep doing the same thing!! Also the products provided to our customers are custom products and need to be designed and built by a company engineer.

summary: "Overall was a very good long term experience with Northrop Grumman.  Good company to work for."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Good benefit package and competetive wages overall.  Good communications from upper management, on critical issues and new programs.  Good holiday and personal time off system.
cons: Shorter term projects (1-2 years duration); required finding next project to cover bench time.  All travel expenses were responsibility of employee, untill reimbursed.
advice_management: Continue good work on communications down the line.  Improve turn around time on travel reinbursements, so employees do not incur credit card interest until reimbursement is paid.

summary: "Overall very positive -- I would gladly work there again."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Very supportive boss and associates.  Very good support for employee education (tuition reimbursement, support for flexible schedule).
cons: We were at a customer site and often felt disconnected from the rest of the company.  We didn't even have full access to the NG corporate intranet from the customer site.
advice_management: Improve internal communications with employees at customer sites and make them feel like part of the company.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great benefits and flexible  hours.
cons: Management plays favoritism, promotes only those that are witin the "manager's circle" which results to  stifling growth and advancement to employees who are top performers.  Threat of retaliation when voicing opinion on serious issues.
advice_management: Management should allow employees to give manager's review and evalutate their performance; need to boost morale within; Re-build employees trust and confidence in  management; promote withing; mentorship.

summary: "It's about the bottom line; employees are ultimately dispensible and their wellfare is unimportant to corporate goals"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Decent pay and benefits; better than not being employed at all.
cons: Constant reorganizations, management by fear and intimidation, managers ill-equiped to do the job required of them, minimal career development support, poor workplace morale...just not a good place.
advice_management: Try leaving the organization as it is, and concentrating on winning new business.  A reorganization won't fix the fact that many senior managers are not competent to perform the job they're assigned.  Management by fear may bring short term results, but it will destroy the business unit in the long run.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Challenging assignments, great people, interesting technologies.
cons: Changing priorities, too frequent reorganizations and changes in management.

summary: "Good place to work to advance career"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Ability to advance career and work in different areas supporting the department of defense.  Opportunities to network with others and develop own career path.  Became more involved with diversity and inclusion.
cons: Need more money for training and educational assistance help employees grow in different areas.  Also there were limitations on moving to other areas if no open positions were not available
advice_management: Continue to communicate openly with subordinates and allow ones who want to advance their careers to network with different senior managers throughout the company.

summary: "No more career growth after 15 years of experience"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: They give Very high pay compared to the rest of industry and they are involved in some interesting work with interesting customers.  It is a good place for young engineers to gain 5 years of experience.
cons:
The defense industry is undergoing a pullback and NG is shrinking faster than management can handle so layoffs are common.  There is also a significant trend toward laying off older engineers (50+).  They get away with it by also laying off token younger engineeers to make it look fair but the real goal is to get rid of high salaries and older people.
Also, once an engineer reachs about 10 or 15 years of experience there is no where to go for career growth.  Promotions are almost non-existent once an engineer has 15 years or so of experience.
It is also common to receive a yearly review that does not match the employee's contribution.  You can walk on water and turn it into wine and still get a below average review if you are not one of the chosen ones who rubs shoudlers with the right people.
advice_management: Wake up before all of your senior talent walks out the back door.  Junior engineers are great if there is someone to lead them in the right direction.  But if you ignore and mistreat the senior engineers you will find yourself with a bunch of junior engineers who cannot take a job to successful completion.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Above average salary and benefits package.  Opportunities to work on high-tech programs/projects.  Eager to hire new/recent college graduates.  Corporate leadership is strong; business unit leadership is variable.
cons: Large company generally means narrow job scope which limits the experience you can gain in any one particular job.  Benefits are slowly and continually being reduced.  Information flow down is poor about current events and nearly nonexistent about the future.  Employees don't have get the feeling they are trusted or valued.  Employees now referred to as "human capital."  Employment cycles up and down with federal government/administration changes.
advice_management: Your most valuable assets are your employees, so reflect that in your management style, decisions, and communications.

summary: "A very bad company for software development"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Relative job stability until there are defense budget cuts. Good retirement benefits.
cons: Terrible management at every level. Relatively low compensation, including salary and benefits. A great deal of bureaucracy for any task.
advice_management: Become leaner and more agile. Value technical excellence. Promote talent and do everything you can to retain it. Improve working conditions.

summary: "Great pay and benefits, Slow pace and low collaboration/innovation"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: It's hard to beat the pay and benefits, which is true of most large government contractors.  They are extremely flexible with hours and work-life balance.
cons: They understandably "follow the money" of government agencies.  As such, I don't find that innovation and change are encouraged.
advice_management: As with most companies that are so geographically spread out, management is quite detached from what's really going on with programs and what the true employee morale is.  If you visit a local campus, provide a charge number so that employees don't have to use up their family time to come hear you talk.

summary: "Fragmented communication and collaboration hinders progress and growth of an otherwise strong company."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Company reputation and capabilities make Northrop Grumman a great place to say you are "from". There are many talented people who work there, even some in leadership positions. Most times, hard work is recognized and rewarded.
cons: As with peer companies, there is little impetus to improve; cost-type, time-and-materials contracts only provide incentive to spend customer money and grow costs, a strategy that is diamertically opposed to customer needs. Change is slow and painful, and is rarely driven from within. Innovation is strictly technical. Processes are heavy and so laden with administrivia that they are rarely followed in any consistent manner. Leadership actions are reactive. Diversification into markets less affected by economic down-turn has lagged. Top jobs go to people who look-like traditional DoD customers (whether or not they display the qualities of great leadership); female and minority representation in management is "token" and heavily weighted toward positions that carry little accountability or authority, espectially with regard to customer relationships (you see the company's "diversity" almost exclusively in HR, Communications, and Administration)..
advice_management: Stop rewarding reactive behavior, no matter how "heroic" it may seem; start rewarding planning. "Bench" or "homeroom" key positions (like Program Managers and Solution Architects) to stop the charge-number dance; make all members of the homeroom accountable to. perform to a set of measurements that are recorded in a common tool (we have them available, PICK ONE).

summary: "NGC is an excellent place to work based on pay, benefits, opportunity and internal training and development."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Interesting products and projects
Large company with lots of locations
Great work and life balance
cons:
Sometimes it can seem too big
It can be hard to influence change

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Salary was  good and they talk a good game, but the are only interested in billing the government.
cons: OMG do these people have their heads wrapped up in process. CMMI is more important to them than writing good software.
advice_management: Get a clue, these shining new BPI things that the MBAs are selling you don't work.

summary: "Over all a great experience, but not a strong corporate presence in New Orleans."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: NG has a vast network and there are a lot of resources that can be utilized.
cons: The company has a small footprint in New Orleans and because of that follow on contracts were few and far between. If you were working for NG in New Orleans, you could not reap the benefits of the vast network without moving.
advice_management: If DOD contracting is going to be your bread and butter, you had better start winning the contracts that are crafting the new DOD and Federal IT architecture/ infrastructure policies.

summary: "Not a horrible place, but be ready for the 'old boys club'"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros:
-Mostly easy going place to work
-Good overall compensation
-9/80 work work allows for nice long weekends
-Nice people in general (like most places)
-Some sophisticated products 
-They usually pay for overtime (straight hours for salaried and time and half for contractors)
cons:
-large bureaucracy  (like most large companies i would imagine)
-A lot of time spent on performance reviews. 

-A tendency to promote people based on association (nepotism is rampant, cronyism too, anyone with management aspirations might do themselves a favor by buying some good golf clubs)

-Very difficult to move between engineering functions. The structures homeroom in Rancho Bernardo has been infiltrated by managers who are known to be confrontational and often give the impression that they have some sort of chip on their shoulder.  Again cronyism superseding good hiring/firing decisions.

-Perhaps the biggest con: The company is  interested in billing the US government for every little thing.  This should upset just about anyone.  

-Upper leadership lacks vision.  I once heard our site director say 'We don't aim to be the best, we just aim to be' .....profound
advice_management: Reward those who work hard and try to bring new innovative ideas to the company.  Its in the best interest of the company to do so. Cronyism keeps a company stale and mediocre!!

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: There are opportunities for advancement but the company has multiple contracts that act as separate entities. Which makes it difficult to advance unless you quit your current job and move to another location.
cons: If you work on-site with the client, you may not get the corporate visibility necessary to move up easily within the company, despite doing incredible work. You may need to work with your manager to self-promote.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: People are great, products are world class. Advancement is hard work not networking. Benefits very good. I would return in the future.
cons: Business development did not do a good job at scanning their external environment, or listening to the customer, so cutbacks. I wasn't but back but saw it coming.
advice_management: Fire your BD team.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Excellent pay that is about the only good thing I can say about the place
cons:
Limited PTO
Incompetent management
Little to no recognition
"class" structure inequalities between "real" employees, and Contract Specific Employees
advice_management: Find some way to treat all your employees as members of the company provide education assistance to CSE's and CSA's.  Remember there are plenty of extremely talented people who could become an incredible asset to the company if allowed to develop professionally.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: They appreciate the work life balance and strive to ensure employees are given oppurtunities to balance work and life. The 9/80 work week is helpful althought not consistent throughout the company, good benefits packages and depending on work location and job many promote working from home.
cons: No room for creative development, everything is dependent on government funding and peoples ability to kiss up and make sure the customer (internal and external are happy. There is no consistency throughout the company.
advice_management: Communicate your needs and stand up for what is good for the company instead of always doing it "that way" because that is how the customer has always seen it.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: global business and diverse product line
cons: poor managment with no communication

summary: "Loosing sight of what matters - Talented people and cutting edge technology"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Salary and benefits
Build hardware that changes the world
cons: Management is mostly interested in cost and schedule, they have lost all sight of keeping an edge technically over the competition.  They are overworking everyone, and their best talent is burning out and leaving to the compettion or they are quick to retire.
advice_management: Your employees are the most valuable asset the company has, they should be treated as more valuable than the share holders.

summary: "Great people to work with, up and down the chain of command."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Great products, great technology, great people.  Good pay, and good educational benefits. 

401k matches plus the company retirement saving account (stay at least 3 years), multiple health insurance plan to choose from, etc.

Manager is great to work with, very understanding, easy to talk to.

For a large company, within a program, the structure is fairly flat, at least in the Aerospace Sector.
cons:
At upper middle management levels, unclear what the career track is.  Some programs take an inordinate amount of dedication and time (hard to balance work), while others are simpler.   
Not easy to change projects.
advice_management: Provide more clarity on how to contribute to the team and how that will impact one's career, if one has aspirations to get into upper management.

summary: "The best big company i ever worked for, great benefit and great management team"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Definitely the benefit package, 401k matches plus the company retirement saving account (stay at least 3 years), multiple health insurance plan to choose from, etc.

Manager is great to work with, very understanding, easy to talk to.
cons: Not easy to change project, most position requires secret clearance.
advice_management: no.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Great co-workers and the best work environment I have ever had. We moved to a new office and shortly after spending millions on an elaborate office, I was laid off due to insufficient funding in the contract I was working.
cons: Defense industry is tough at times. This office did not put forth an good effort to win new business. As a result if the trend continues the office will close. Also  Northrop Grumman does not contest  lost contract awards even when there are sufficient grounds to protest.
advice_management: Win new business

summary: "It's working for a big company, with lots of interesting work and lots of bureaucracy"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Decent benefits, good pay, somewhat flexible hours.  Able to maintain a work life balance. As a major contractor they get lots of work so something is always going on somewhere. 9/80 schedule.
cons: Feels like many little companies in one. Middle management seems to try to maintain individual fiefdoms so sharing across programs doesn't happen often or easily. Impossible to get rid of incompetent employees, and its pretty easy to stay under the radar and just "get by" (though that might be a pro for some people).  How and why people get promotions seems inconsistent, and its never before time in grade requirements are met.
advice_management: Get managers with backgrounds delivering truly exceptional software to build up processes that will retain excellent software engineers.  This goes from interviewing, to providing reasonable work spaces, getting development tools, and measuring and rewarding performance.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Corporate has longer term plan than some defense contractors, and more willing to invest in R&D projects to capture markets.
cons: Review process is a joke. If you get a bad project manager, you can forget any career advancement.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Smart Coworkers, cool work, challenging tasks.  There is a lot of opportunity to grow.  There is also a lot of opportunity to learn.
cons: There are several slow periods.  There are also times when you are waiting for a position prior to having a clearance.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Job security, easy, interesting travel
cons: Just another fat cat defense contractor that has more employees than work.  A waste of tax payer money.
advice_management: quit empire building - it's unethical to use tax payer money to have excessive employees.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: great people; great morals; quality work
cons: politics; slow moving decisions; lack of innovation/creativity
advice_management: focus on employee engagement and retention (especially for Gen Y)...from my experience, you are doing it all wrong.

summary: "The overall company is great;  some of the business units and sectors are worse than awful"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Good salaries and benefits packages
cons:
Revolving door of management - each has slightly different priorites
No work-life balance
Very political
advice_management: Be honest with your employees

summary: "Northrop Grumman Information Technology Is Not What it Seems"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Beneifits, my coworkers, time off, and a pretty building.
cons: Lack of Opportunities, Communication, and compensation is well below the national average.
advice_management: Listen to your employees. Doing the same thing day in and day out is not a method of business improvement.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Good salary and benefits.  Ability to transfer within the corporation to other jobs or locations both within the US and foreign countries
cons: Its very obvious that it's a large corporation in that  communication between departments is inefficient.  Remote locations are pretty much cut off from corporate.
advice_management: Streamline the processes between departments.  i.e.  human resources and the benefits divisions seem out of touch with one another.  One would think they would have easy access to each others data.  Spending two hours on the phone to confirm benefits is a waste of time on both ends

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: A great way to meet younger people, especially if you are new to the area.
cons: Difficult to get promoted.  They do not pay as much as other defense contractors.
advice_management: Spend more time shaping your employees.

summary: "Good, challenging work but management seems set on outsourcing everything"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Good engineers. Nice facility in Maitland. Plenty of resources - i have everything I need to do my job. Interesting work.
cons: outsourcing to nearby companies and paying them the same amount you pay your people except we fire our people because we can't afford them. funding problems. And I am not one who got laid off.
advice_management: keep work inside instead of laying people off. strategic partnerships are a joke.

summary: "Great work, but few opportunities for advancement"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Meaningful assignments, decent compensation, good wor/life balance.
cons: political nature of advancements, siloed communications, difficulty of finding information necessary to getting the work done.

summary: "Large corporation, cubicle farm, etc.  Not difficult work, straight 9-5 stuff."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Work life balance is very good.  You don't need to work crazy hours.  If you like defense or engineering and have a family, this is potentially a great place for you.
cons: You are working for a massive corporation - unless you wanna park your butt in a cubicle for 30 years (which I definitely did not) this isn't for you.  It is very corporate, things don't move fast, everything can be de-humanizing and boring most of the time.
advice_management: Keep pushing for results, because honestly, its such a massive corporation one man change the culture but one person can definitely make some money at this place.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: It has the resources of a large company.
cons: Location was far from headquarters.
advice_management: Pay more attention to units.

summary: "i have had a generally positive experience working for Northrop."
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: It is what you make of it.  Large amount of online training available, PMP, business, leadership, etc.  Great Benefits with a good deal of flexiblity for time off.
cons: Large organization.  Many stovepiped efforts.  It can depend on the contract you support.  The contract I support does not allow for much interaction with the rest of the company.

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: management recognizes employee contributions and is supportive of career advancement
cons: less flexible then other companies

summary: "fine place to work at the beginning"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Nice place to start as an engineer, they offer tuition reimbursement and various training opportunities (computer skill, online training etc).
Good benefits and pay.
Overall, work life balance is good
Generally, people are easy to work with and have talent
cons:
Not many new business come in
Senior management put more focus on people skill instead of technical skill
Manufacturing oriented, not much effort on R&D
Layoffs happen everywhere recently, job is not as stable as before
advice_management:
Win more new contracts. Put your eyes on commercial side not just government side.
Value your technical people and encourage innovation
Don't let go of good people during tough time.

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Work remote, good salary, great people
cons: Some uncertainies of future positions

main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros: Pay is great, sense of purpose in your job, benefits, and travel
cons: Government politics effect your job.
advice_management: Northrop needs to be more seamless between the sectors in shared work and processes

main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: The work environment was very comfortable; Flexable work hours allowed employees to come and go with in reason; The work was always interesting and challenging
cons: Government contract work is often not stable; often it was strongly suggested that we work overtme without additional pay; annual salary increases were based on job performance but were often unfair and ranged from 1% to 5%; When government contracts are cut there are usually extensive layoffs in the entire industry flooding the job market with many workers in your field.
advice_management: It is important to add some additional compensation to employees who routinely work extra hours; Efforts to keep long term employees need to be improved

summary: "Company is gone, so it doesn't matter anymore.  Too big to fail."
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros: Pay, paid holidays, PTO, 4 day work week. All of that is gone now. Northrop Grumman doesn't own the shipyard anymore.
cons: The shipyard isn't owned by Northrop Grumman anymore.  It was "too big to fail".
advice_management: They won't change. The new company put the same old dog and pony show up front.  Good luck!  Too big to fail. The new company owns the yard AND the debt.

summary: "Just fine for a large defense contractor"
main_text: I worked at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Good work/life balance (typically 40 hour weeks)
Decent benefits (health, dental, 401k)
Reasonable salary
Good educational reimbursement
Flexible hours / time off
cons:
Mix of quality and not-so-quality people
Depending on the program, sometimes outdated technology is used
More meetings / time overhead than smaller companies
Periodic layoffs (10% or so)
advice_management:
Work harder at acquiring new business (this is important)
Focus on keeping good employees happy
Encourage use of newer technologies

summary: "Difficult to fit in mid-career; but fine products, people"
main_text: I have been working at Northrop Grumman
pros:
Talented engineers with integrity
Professional work environment
Good work/life balance
Significant national security programs
Variety of programs to work on (reasonably diversified business)
cons:
Misalignment of incentives - emphasis upon financial performance, but no rewards to rank-and-file
Poor vision from senior management
Insufficient efforts to win new business
advice_management: Bonuses should be flowed bonuses down much further; and/or, make success sharing driven more by project accomplishments.  Encourage a more entrepreneurial culture, one that incentivizes the prudent taking of risks.  Continue to reduce levels of hierarchy.
